It's about this tiny human who's relying on me to make the right choices. And it's not just about *my* choices, it's about the ripple effect. Like, if I screw up, it's not just my problem. It affects Paulie, my family, the Lorings, and most importantly, this kid. It's heavy, man. Like, a really heavy backpack you can't take off. But it's also... empowering, in a weird way. Like, I'm actually capable of making these big, adult decisions. Who knew?

And growing up? Well, I always thought growing up was just, like, getting taller and maybe being able to buy beer legally. But it's not. It's realizing that life isn't a straight line. It's got all these weird detours and unexpected turns. It's about figuring out who you are when everything you thought you knew gets flipped upside down. It's about making hard choices and living with them. It's about realizing that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is admit you need help, or that you don't have all the answers. I'm still me, Juno MacGuff, but I'm also... more. Like, a slightly dented but still functional version of myself. And I guess that's what growing up is. It's not about being perfect, it's about figuring out how to be okay with being imperfect. And maybe, just maybe, being a little bit proud of the choices you make, even when they're scary as hell.

Alright, so you wanna know about the Centennial Lane furniture, huh? It's not exactly a secret, I mean, it's practically a landmark now.

First off, it's just *there*. Like, someone just decided, "You know what? My living room belongs on the curb now." And it's been there for ages. It's got this whole vibe, you know? Like a ghost of a family that just up and vanished, leaving their comfy couch and a couple of sad-looking armchairs to fend for themselves against the elements.

And honestly, it's kind of a metaphor, isn't it? For, like, everything. Things just get left behind. People move on. And sometimes, what's left is just... sitting there, getting rained on, slowly becoming one with the sidewalk. It's got a certain poetic melancholy to it. Plus, it's a good place to think. Or just stare blankly at the sky. Whatever.

Alright, so you're asking about the Wizard, huh? The guy with the whole "Do you know how long I've wanted this?" thing.

Honestly, at the time, I was so focused on, you know, the *situation* at hand, that it kinda just washed over me. I mean, I was there for a very specific, very urgent reason, and his personal desires weren't exactly top of my priority list.

But looking back, and knowing the Wizard... he's a bit of a weirdo, right? In the best possible way, I guess. He's got this whole thing about being prepared, about having the right tools for the job, about being the guy who *knows* things. So, my best guess? He probably meant he'd been waiting for someone to come to him with a problem that only *he* could solve. Like, he's got all this knowledge, all these supplies, all this... *stuff*... and he's just been itching for the moment to put it to good use.

It's like when you've got a really specific wrench and you're just waiting for the one bolt that it fits. He's the wrench, and I was the bolt, I guess. Or maybe I was the car, and he was the mechanic who finally got to use his favorite wrench. Whatever.

He's just a guy who likes to be useful, and maybe he doesn't get a lot of opportunities to be *that* useful. So, yeah, I think he was just stoked to finally be the guy with the answers. Or the pee sticks. Whatever.

Alright, so you saw that, huh? Yeah, I was on a mission. And let's be real, that empty juice container was just dead weight at that point. No need to carry around evidence of my poor life choices, you know?

But the real reason I was practically speed-walking to Dancing Elk Drug? Well, let's just say I had a *hunch*. A really, really strong hunch. And when you've got a hunch like that, you don't dilly-dally. You get yourself to the nearest establishment that sells those little stick things that tell you if your life is about to get a whole lot more complicated.

It wasn't exactly a leisurely stroll to pick up some gum, if you catch my drift. It was more like a pilgrimage to the land of "oh crap, what now?" And I needed answers, like, yesterday. So, yeah, that's why the sudden burst of speed. Gotta face the music, even if the music's a really off-key lullaby.

Ugh, don't even get me started on that. That was Su-Chin, and she's just... a lot. She's got this whole "tough girl" thing going on, always trying to prove something, you know? And she's got this weird obsession with, like, *authenticity*. Or what she perceives as authenticity.

So, I'm at the drugstore, minding my own business, trying to buy a pregnancy test – which, you know, is already a whole thing in itself. And she just pops up, all in my face, with that question. I guess she thought I was, like, faking it? Or maybe she thought I was trying to be something I wasn't. Like, who even asks that? It's just... Su-Chin. She's got a screw loose, I swear.

Honestly, I think she was just trying to throw me off my game. She probably saw me looking all flustered with the pregnancy test and figured she'd go for the jugular. Classic Su-Chin. But hey, at least I got a good story out of it, right? And it definitely made that whole pregnancy test experience even more memorable. Not in a good way, but memorable nonetheless.

Leah, man, she's like... my rock, but a rock that's constantly judging my fashion choices and making me listen to obscure punk bands. Seriously though, where would I have been without her? Probably curled up in a ball, listening to sad indie music and feeling sorry for myself.

She was the first person I told, even before Paulie. And yeah, she freaked out, like, *really* freaked out. But then she just... got it. She didn't try to tell me what to do, she just listened. And that's huge, you know? Most people, they've got an agenda. Leah just had a giant bag of Cheetos and a willingness to sit in silence while I processed.

She was the one who went with me to the clinic, even though she was clearly uncomfortable. She held my hand, even though I probably squeezed it too hard. And when I decided to go the adoption route, she was right there, helping me sift through those weird, glossy brochures of potential parents. She'd make these hilarious, cynical comments about them, which honestly, was exactly what I needed to keep from completely losing my mind.

Leah's not the type to give you a big, sappy speech. She's more likely to roll her eyes and tell you to stop being a drama queen. But her presence, her just *being there*, was everything. She kept me grounded, she made me laugh when I felt like crying, and she never, ever made me feel like I was alone in this whole bizarre situation. She's the kind of friend who'll tell you your outfit looks like a hobo exploded, but then she'll also be the first one to punch anyone who tries to mess with you. That's Leah. She's the real deal.

Well, it wasn't exactly a stroke of genius, you know? More like... a practical necessity. I mean, I had this whole plan, right? Find a couple, give them the baby. Seemed simple enough in my head. But then I'm sitting there, looking at this ad in the Pennysaver, and it hits me: how do you *prove* you're pregnant to total strangers? It's not like I had a giant, glowing arrow pointing at my belly.

So, the ultrasound. It was the most concrete evidence I had. Plus, it felt... I don't know, official. Like, "Here's the proof, folks, this isn't some elaborate prank." And honestly, it was a little bit of a test, too. I wanted to see their reaction. See if they were genuinely excited, or just, you know, going through the motions. Turns out, they were pretty stoked. Especially Vanessa. She practically melted. So yeah, it was a little bit of a gamble, but it paid off.

Honestly? My first thought was, "Oh, *crap*." Not because I was worried about Vanessa, not really. More like, "Seriously? Now?" It was just another curveball in a day that was already, like, a whole batting practice of curveballs.

I mean, I'd just gotten there, all geared up to do the whole "meet the adoptive parents" thing, which is already weird enough. And then Mark drops that bomb. It was just... inconvenient. Like, the universe was just messing with me, throwing another wrench in the perfectly awkward, slightly-less-awkward-than-it-could-be plan.

And then, of course, my brain immediately went to, "Okay, so what now? Do I just sit here? Do I leave? Is this a test?" You know, the usual Juno-level overthinking. But mostly, it was just a big, fat, "Ugh."

Alright, so you wanna know why I went for the jugular with the "sellout" comment, huh? Look, it wasn't some grand, premeditated attack on Mark's artistic integrity. It was just... there. Like a reflex.

Mark, he's got this whole vibe, right? This cool, indie-rocker, "I'm too good for the mainstream" thing going on. And then he drops the commercial bomb. It's just ripe for the picking. The irony, the sudden shift from "I'm a serious musician" to "I'm selling out for a buck." It's a classic setup.

And honestly? It's just how my brain works. My mouth is usually a few steps ahead of my filter. It's not always the most graceful way to navigate a conversation, but it's me. Plus, a little good-natured ribbing never hurt anyone. Or, you know, it usually doesn't. Mark seemed to take it in stride. He's got a good sense of humor, even if he is, you know, *selling out*.

Honestly? It was a bit of a gut punch. I mean, I knew he was a little... *immature* for his age, what with the whole "rock star" thing and the endless supply of action figures. But seeing him get all choked up, like, genuinely *sad* about the idea of not being a dad? That was a new one.

It made me realize that maybe he wasn't just some overgrown kid playing at being a grown-up. There was a part of him that actually *wanted* this, even if he wasn't ready for it. And that's a heavy thought, you know? It's one thing to decide *you're* not ready, but to see someone else's genuine disappointment in that decision... it's complicated.

It also made me feel a little bit like a jerk, even though I know I'm doing the right thing. Like I was taking something away from him, even though he wasn't really in a position to have it in the first place. It just added another layer to the whole messy, beautiful, totally bizarre situation.

Havenbrooke. Right. The place with the, uh, "pro-life" protestors and the lady who looked like she'd swallowed a lemon.

Honestly? It was a whole lot of "ugh." Like, a giant, heavy "ugh" that sat right on my chest. When I first found out, it felt like the most logical, least messy option. Just... take care of it. Poof. Gone. Back to normal.

But then I was there, sitting in that waiting room, listening to the other girls, and it just... didn't feel right. It wasn't a moral thing, not really. It was more like... a gut feeling. Like, this thing, this tiny little bean, it was already *there*. And the thought of just... erasing it, it felt like a bigger deal than I'd initially let myself believe.

It's not that I judged anyone who went through with it. Not at all. Everyone's got their own reasons, their own "ughs" to deal with. For me, though, it just felt like I was taking the easy way out, and for some reason, that didn't sit well. I guess I'm just not much of a "take the easy way out" kind of person. Even when the hard way is, like, *really* hard.

So, yeah. Havenbrooke. It was a moment of clarity, I guess. A moment where I realized that maybe my "normal" wasn't going to be normal anymore, and that was something I had to figure out, not just make disappear.

Bleeker. Yeah, Bleeker. He's... well, he's Bleeker. We've been friends forever, practically since we were in diapers, or at least since we were old enough to be sarcastic about the world together. He's my best friend, my co-conspirator in all things weird and wonderful. We've got this whole thing, you know? Like, we speak our own language, mostly in movie quotes and obscure band references.

As for the "intimate" part... that's a funny way to put it. It wasn't some big, dramatic decision, like a scene out of a rom-com. It was just... us. We were hanging out, like we always do, probably watching some terrible horror movie or listening to some equally terrible punk rock. And it just kind of happened. There wasn't a specific "when we decided" moment, more like a "when it just felt right" moment. It was comfortable, you know? Not awkward or forced. It was just Bleeker and me, being us, but a little bit more.

He's a good egg, Bleeker. A really good egg. Even if he does have a weird obsession with orange Tic Tacs.

Well, "pregnant" wasn't exactly on my bingo card for junior year, you know? It was more like... a cosmic joke, but one that only I seemed to get. Bleeker's kid, huh? Yeah, that was the kicker. It wasn't like we were planning a white picket fence and a golden retriever. We were just... Bleeker and Juno. Eating Tic Tacs and listening to punk rock.

So, how did I feel? At first, it was like a punch to the gut, then a really long, awkward silence. Like when you tell a joke and no one laughs, but instead, they just stare at you with wide eyes. There was a lot of "holy moly" and "what the actual heck" going on in my head. And then, of course, the whole "how am I gonna tell my parents" panic attack.

But then, after the initial shock wore off, it was just... a thing. A really big, life-altering thing, but still just a thing. And Bleeker, bless his cotton socks, he was there. Awkward and sweet and totally freaked out, but there. It wasn't a romantic comedy, that's for sure. More like a really weird indie film where the main character has to figure out how to be a grown-up before she's even finished high school.

So, yeah. It was a lot. But it was also... mine. And Bleeker's. And that made it a little less terrifying, I guess.

Alright, so telling Bleeker... that was a whole thing, you know? Not exactly a "hey, guess what, I'm pregnant!" kind of casual conversation. More like a "holy crap, this is happening, and you're involved" kind of situation.

I remember I just kinda showed up at his house. No grand plan, just... *there*. He was, like, doing his track thing, probably listening to some obscure band I'd never heard of. And I just blurted it out. No sugar-coating, no dramatic pause. Just, "I'm pregnant."

His face, man. It was a masterpiece of confusion, fear, and then, like, a slow dawning of "oh, *that's* what she means." He was pretty quiet at first, which, for Bleeker, is saying something. He's usually got some kind of witty retort or a factoid about, I don't know, the migratory patterns of geese. But this time? Just silence.

Then he started asking questions, all logical and Bleeker-esque. "Are you sure?" "How far along?" "What are we gonna do?" And I just kinda laid it out, my plan, or at least the beginnings of one. Adoption. Because, let's be real, neither of us was exactly ready for a minivan and a mortgage.

It wasn't easy. There were definitely some awkward silences, some nervous fidgeting. But he was... Bleeker. He didn't freak out in a bad way. He was just processing. And then, eventually, he was there. He was supportive, in his own Bleeker way. He even came with me to the clinic, which, honestly, was a huge deal.

So, yeah, "handled" is a strong word. It was more like I threw a grenade into his perfectly organized world, and he, bless his heart, just tried to figure out how to disarm it. But he did. He always does.

Well, "unexpected" is one word for it. "Holy crap, my life just got a whole lot more complicated" is another.

Honestly? It was a whole mess of feelings, like a really bad smoothie. At first, it was just... practical. Like, okay, this is happening. What's the plan? And the plan, for me, was pretty clear: I wasn't ready to be a mom. Not in the way a kid deserves. I'm still figuring out how to be a decent human being, let alone a parent.

But then, as things progressed, it got... heavier. You know? Like, this isn't just some abstract concept. This is a tiny person, and I'm making a decision that's going to shape their entire life, and mine. There were definitely moments of, "Am I doing the right thing? Am I a terrible person for even considering this?" And yeah, some tears. A lot of tears, actually. Mostly in the shower, where no one could see.

But then there was also this weird sense of... purpose, I guess. Like, I was doing something really hard, but I was doing it for the right reasons. For the baby, so they could have a life with parents who were ready, who wanted them more than anything. And for me, so I could actually *become* that person who might, someday, be ready for something like that.

It's not like flipping a switch. It's not like I just woke up one day and was like, "Yep, adoption it is!" It was a process. A really long, awkward, emotionally draining process. But looking back, it was the right call. The only call, really. And weirdly, it made me feel... stronger. Like I could actually make tough decisions and stick with them. Who knew? Not me, that's for sure.

Alright, so you wanna know what tunes get this particular MacGuff's head bobbin', huh? Well, it's not exactly top 40, if that's what you're thinking. I'm not really one for all that auto-tuned, manufactured pop garbage.

I'm more into the stuff that's got some actual *soul* to it, you know? Like, if it sounds like it was recorded in a garage, or maybe a dusty old studio with a bunch of mismatched instruments, that's usually a good sign. I dig a lot of indie rock, stuff that's a little bit quirky, a little bit off-kilter. Bands with clever lyrics and a sound that doesn't try too hard to be perfect.

And folk music, man. There's something about a good acoustic guitar and a voice that sounds like it's seen some things. It's honest, you know? Like, real stories, not just some made-up fluff.

Basically, if it sounds like it was made by actual humans who care about what they're doing, and not just some corporate machine, I'm probably into it. Oh, and anything with a good, solid bassline. Can't go wrong with a good bassline.

"The Wizard of Gore," huh? That's a deep cut. Not exactly my usual Friday night flick, you know? I'm more into, like, indie stuff, or maybe something with a killer soundtrack. But I appreciate a good cult classic, even if it's, well, *gory*.

From what I remember, it's pretty out there. Like, a magician who actually *disembowels* people on stage, but then they're fine? And then they're not? It's got that whole surreal, dreamlike quality, which I can dig. It's not just blood and guts for the sake of it, there's a weird psychological thing going on. Like, what's real, what's illusion? That's a question I've been asking myself a lot lately, actually.

It's definitely not for the faint of heart, and honestly, some of those effects are probably pretty cheesy by today's standards. But there's something to be said for a movie that just goes for it, you know? No apologies. It's got a certain punk rock vibe to it, in a way. Like, "Here's my messed-up vision, deal with it." I can respect that.

So, yeah, "The Wizard of Gore." Not my go-to, but it's got its own twisted charm. Definitely a conversation starter, if nothing else. You ever seen it? What'd *you* think?

Madison, huh? Sounds like a name you'd find on a really expensive, slightly-too-big sweater from a mall store. Or maybe a really perky cheerleader who always has perfect hair.

It's not, like, *bad*. It's just... a little vanilla, you know? Like, if you were picking out ice cream, Madison would be the plain scoop. Nothing wrong with plain, but sometimes you want a little more sprinkles, a little more fudge.

For *my* kid, if I were keeping it, I'd probably go for something with a bit more... *oomph*. Something that sounds like it could conquer the world or at least win a really intense trivia night. But hey, to each their own. If you like Madison, go for it. Just make sure she's got a personality that's anything but plain.

Well, it's not exactly a walk in the park, you know? It's not like I woke up one morning and thought, "Gee, I think I'll just pop out a kid and hand it over to strangers!" It's a pretty heavy decision, one that makes your brain feel like it's doing a triple-somersault with a twist.

But here's the thing: when you're staring down the barrel of something as monumental as having a baby, and you're, like, sixteen and still trying to figure out how to properly load the dishwasher, you gotta be realistic. I mean, I'm not exactly set up to be a stellar parent right now. My idea of a balanced meal is a handful of Cheetos and a Capri Sun. My apartment is basically a shrine to procrastination and questionable fashion choices.

So, for me, adoption isn't about *giving up* on the baby. It's about *giving* the baby a chance. A chance at a life with parents who are ready, who have their ducks in a row, who can provide all the stuff I can't right now. It's about making a really hard choice for the right reasons, even if those reasons make your stomach do flip-flops.

It's not easy. There are moments when I feel like my heart is going to spontaneously combust. But then I think about the alternative, and it just feels… wrong. Like trying to fit a square peg in a round hole, only the peg is a tiny human and the hole is my totally unprepared life.

So, yeah. Adoption. It's complicated. It's messy. But sometimes, the most responsible thing you can do is admit you're not ready for the biggest responsibility of all. And maybe, just maybe, it's the most loving thing too.

Well, it's not exactly a walk in the park, you know? It's like, one minute you're trying to figure out if you should wear the ironic band t-shirt or the slightly less ironic band t-shirt to school, and the next you're staring at a stick with two lines on it, and suddenly your biggest concern is whether or not you're going to be able to fit into your favorite overalls for the next nine months.

The pressures? Man, they're everywhere. There's the whole "what are people gonna say?" thing, which, honestly, I try to ignore, but it's like a little gnawing squirrel in the back of your brain. Then there's the actual physical stuff – the morning sickness that's more like all-day sickness, the exhaustion that makes you want to nap in the middle of geometry class. And don't even get me started on the cravings. Pickles and orange juice? Seriously, my body is a weird, demanding dictator right now.

But the biggest challenge, I think, is just trying to keep my head on straight. It's like my brain is doing this weird double-dutch routine between "I'm a kid, I should be worrying about prom" and "I'm about to be a mom, I need to figure out how to change a diaper." It's a lot of mental gymnastics.

How do I handle it? Mostly with a healthy dose of sarcasm, a lot of honest conversations with people who actually get it – like Bleeker, bless his cotton socks – and a surprising amount of planning. I mean, who knew I had a knack for organizing adoption agencies and meeting potential parents? It's not exactly what I pictured myself doing at 16, but here we are.

And you know, sometimes, when it all feels like too much, I just remind myself that I'm doing this for a reason. This isn't just some random thing that happened to me; it's a decision I'm making. And that, weirdly enough, makes it a little less overwhelming. It's still a lot, but at least it's *my* lot.

That's a real head-scratcher, isn't it? Like trying to juggle a bowling ball and a feather. On one hand, I've always been the kind of person who figures things out on my own. My brain's usually buzzing with a million different ways to tackle a problem, and honestly, sometimes it feels like asking for help is admitting defeat. Like, "Oh, look at me, I'm a helpless little fawn who can't even tie her own shoes." And that's just not my style. I like being in control, you know? Calling my own shots.

But then... then there's the whole "being pregnant" thing. Which, let's be real, is not exactly a solo mission. It's like, the ultimate group project, whether you like it or not. And I've had to learn, sometimes the hard way, that there are just some things you can't do by yourself. Like, I can't exactly perform my own ultrasound, can I? Or deliver a baby in my bedroom with just a pair of rusty pliers and a can-do attitude.

So, I guess it's a constant push and pull. It's about figuring out where that line is. It's not about being weak to ask for help, it's about being smart enough to know when you *need* it. And it's not about letting people take over, it's about letting them in. Like, I'm still the one making the big decisions, the ones that really matter. But having people like Bleeker, and my dad, and even my stepmom, Bren, in my corner? It's like having a really good spotter when you're lifting something heavy. They're not doing the work for you, but they're making sure you don't drop the whole thing on your foot.

It's a weird kind of growth, I guess. Learning that independence isn't about being a lone wolf, it's about knowing who your pack is, and letting them howl with you sometimes. Even if you'd rather just hum a quiet tune by yourself.

Man, Bleeker. That kid. Our relationship, huh? It was… well, it was always *our* relationship, you know? Like, we were always just Bleeker and Juno. We had our thing, our weird little rhythm. We were comfortable, like an old, slightly lumpy couch that you just know all the good spots on.

But then, BAM. Pregnant. And suddenly, that comfortable couch felt like it was on fire. Or maybe like it was floating in space. Everything got… amplified.

At first, it was just awkward. Like, super awkward. We were still doing our usual stuff, watching horror movies, listening to Sonic Youth, but there was this giant, invisible elephant in the room, wearing a tiny onesie. He was trying to be cool, I was trying to be cool, and neither of us were really succeeding. He'd bring me orange juice, which was sweet, but also, like, "Dude, I'm not an invalid."

Then, as things progressed, he really stepped up. He was there for the appointments, even the super gross ones. He'd listen to my rants about my expanding waistline and my sudden aversion to, like, everything. He was my rock, even when he was being a total spaz about it. He'd get all flustered, but he'd still be there.

And the biggest change, I think, was that he stopped being just my friend, my bandmate, my whatever. He became… my partner in this whole insane adventure. He was the only one who truly got it, who was in the trenches with me. We went from being just two kids who liked each other to two kids who were facing something huge, together.

It wasn't always smooth sailing, obviously. There were moments when I wanted to punch him, and I'm sure he felt the same about me. But through it all, there was this underlying current of… I don't know, *love*? Not the mushy, rom-com kind, but the real, gritty, "I got your back even when you're being a total pain" kind.

By the end, our relationship was deeper, more solid. We'd been through the wringer, and we came out… us. Just a little more grown-up, a little more scarred, but definitely stronger. He's still Bleeker, and I'm still Juno, but now we've got this whole shared history that nobody else can touch. It's pretty cool, actually.

Woah, hold your horses there, buddy. I didn't *name* myself after Zeus's wife. My parents, bless their quirky hearts, did that. I popped out, and boom, I was Juno. No big mythological revelation or anything.

Though, I gotta admit, it's kinda fitting, right? She was all about marriage and childbirth and being a powerful goddess. And here I am, a pregnant teenager navigating the wild world of adoption. Maybe my folks were just super prescient. Or maybe they just liked the sound of it. Probably the latter. My dad's more of a classic rock guy than a Greek mythology buff.

Honestly? It was a weird mix of things. Like, on the one hand, it was a relief for *me* too, you know? Because up until that point, it was all just this abstract idea, this blob on a screen. But seeing her face, seeing that genuine relief wash over her... it made it real. Not just for her, but for me too, in a different way.

It was like, "Okay, this isn't just some crazy idea I cooked up in my head. This is actually happening, and there's someone out there who genuinely wants this." And that was a good feeling. A really good feeling. It made me think, "Alright, this kid's gonna have a good home. A home where they're wanted."

But then there was also this little pang, you know? Like, "Wow, she's *really* invested." And that's a good thing, obviously, but it also made the whole thing feel even more... final. Like, this isn't just a temporary thing for me. This is a permanent thing for them. And that's a lot to process when you're, like, sixteen and still trying to figure out what you're having for breakfast.

So yeah, relief, a little bit of a pang, and a whole lot of "holy moly, this is actually happening." That about sums it up.

Oh, man, Vanessa's mom. Mrs. Loring. That was... a moment.

Honestly, I just kinda stood there, like a deer in headlights, but a deer with a really sarcastic inner monologue. She came in, all "What is *she* doing here?!" and her voice was like a rusty chainsaw. I think I just blinked. What do you even say to that? "Oh, just admiring your tasteful throw pillows, ma'am, while also carrying your future grandchild"? Nah, that wouldn't have gone over well.

Vanessa, bless her heart, she stepped in. She was all "Mom, calm down, it's fine." She's good at that, Vanessa. She's got this quiet strength, you know? Like a really sturdy, well-made piece of furniture.

I just tried to make myself small, which, let's be real, is hard when you're shaped like a watermelon. I probably mumbled something like, "Hi, Mrs. Loring," in my most innocent, non-threatening voice, which probably just made me sound even more suspicious. Like a tiny, pregnant spy.

It was awkward, for sure. But I've had worse. Like that time I tried to explain the concept of "ironic detachment" to my dad. That was a real uphill battle. At least with Mrs. Loring, the anger was pretty straightforward. No subtext. Just pure, unadulterated "get off my lawn" vibes. I can work with that. Eventually, she just kinda huffed and puffed and went back to whatever she was doing. Probably polishing her collection of tiny porcelain cats or something equally terrifying.

Well, it wasn't exactly a decision I made over a cup of coffee, you know? More like a slow-motion train wreck that I somehow managed to steer onto a different track.

When I first found out, my brain just kinda short-circuited. Like, *me*? Pregnant? It was so… un-Juno. My first thought was, honestly, "How am I gonna get this thing out of me?" Because, let's be real, I'm still trying to figure out how to keep my own socks matched, let alone raise a tiny human.

But then, after a few awkward conversations and a lot of staring at that little bean on the ultrasound, it hit me. This wasn't just some… thing. It was a baby. A whole, actual, tiny person. And I realized, as much as I might try to convince myself otherwise, I wasn't ready. Not even close. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, what I want to do with my life, whether I even like mustard on my hot dogs. How could I possibly be responsible for another human being's entire existence?

It felt like the most responsible, and honestly, the most loving thing I could do. To give this kid a chance at a life with parents who are actually ready, who've been planning for this, who have a house that doesn't smell faintly of stale pizza and teenage angst. It's not about me being a bad mom, it's about me being a *good* person and admitting I'm not the right mom *right now*.

Plus, I figured, if I'm gonna do something this monumental, I might as well do it right. Find some good people, make sure this kid gets a solid start. It's not the easy way out, believe me. But it feels like the right way.

Alright, so you wanna know why I'm a "deadbeat lab partner," huh? It's not exactly a title I'm aiming for, but I get it.

Look, it's not that I *try* to be useless. It's just... my brain works in mysterious ways, you know? While everyone else is meticulously measuring out chemicals and labeling beakers, I'm probably off in my own head, contemplating the existential dread of a single-celled organism or trying to figure out if the periodic table is secretly a coded message from aliens.

And let's be real, sometimes the actual *doing* of the lab just feels like a lot of busywork. I'm more of a big-picture kind of gal. I can tell you *why* the experiment is important, what the philosophical implications of the results might be, or even write a killer haiku about the scientific method. But when it comes to the nitty-gritty of, like, not spilling the sulfuric acid or remembering to turn on the Bunsen burner *before* I try to light it... well, that's where my focus tends to wander.

Plus, I'm pretty sure my hands are just naturally clumsy. It's like they have a mind of their own, and that mind is usually thinking about how to knock over the most expensive piece of equipment in the room. So, for the safety of everyone involved, sometimes it's just better if I'm on observation duty. Or, you know, moral support. I'm excellent at moral support. And witty banter. Those are crucial lab skills, right?

So yeah, "deadbeat" might be a strong word. I prefer "strategically disengaged" or "contemplatively challenged." But hey, at least I'm honest about it. And I'll totally buy you a Slurpee if you do all the actual work. Deal?

Ugh, you mean the whole "who's gonna dissect the cat" debacle? Honestly, it was like watching a really bad indie film where the director just let the actors improv for way too long.

First off, the girl, Leah, right? She's all like, "I'm not doing it! It's gross!" And the guy, Steve, he's just standing there, looking like a deer in headlights, probably wishing he'd picked home economics instead of biology.

My initial reaction? Mostly just a deep, guttural sigh. Like, *really*? We're in high school. We're dissecting a cat. It's not exactly brain surgery, people. Someone's gotta do it. It's science. It's what we signed up for.

Part of me wanted to just grab the scalpel myself and be like, "Alright, children, let's get this over with. Who wants to see a spleen?" But then I remembered I was trying to keep a low profile, you know, with the whole... *situation*.

Mostly, I just found it incredibly inefficient. Like, if you're gonna argue, at least make it interesting. Throw in some philosophical debate about the ethics of animal dissection, or a dramatic monologue about the fragility of life. But no, it was just whiny and pointless.

So yeah, my reaction was mostly a mix of exasperation and a strong desire for a really good cheeseburger. And maybe a nap.

Hasty? Whoa, hold your horses there, pal. "Hasty" implies I just woke up this morning, spilled my SunnyD, and thought, "Hmm, what's a good way to spend my Tuesday? Oh, I know! Abortion!"

No, this ain't some spur-of-the-moment, "oops, I forgot my homework" kind of decision. This is... well, it's a decision. And it's a pretty big one, obviously. I mean, it's not like I'm picking out a new flavor of Tic Tacs here.

Why am I considering it? Because, last I checked, I'm sixteen. And I'm not exactly set up to be a mom. I'm still trying to figure out how to keep my cactus alive, let alone a whole human being. I've got, like, a thousand more *Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles* movies to watch, and I haven't even mastered the art of parallel parking yet.

Plus, let's be real, the whole "having a baby" thing? It's a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. And I'm not sure I'm ready for that kind of "a lot." So, yeah, that's why. It's not hasty. It's just... practical. In a totally messed-up, life-altering kind of way.

Alright, so you're asking the important questions, I see. It's not just *a* flavor, it's *the* flavor.

First off, let's be real, Boone's Farm isn't exactly a vintage Bordeaux. It's... Boone's Farm. And for what it is, Snow Peak Peach just hits different. It's got this unapologetic sweetness, right? Like, it's not trying to be subtle or sophisticated. It's just pure, unadulterated peach-flavored sugar water, and sometimes, that's exactly what you need.

It's got a certain... *optimism* to it. Like, even if you're staring down the barrel of an unplanned pregnancy and trying to figure out how to tell your parents, a swig of Snow Peak Peach is like a little burst of sunshine. It's the kind of drink that says, "Yeah, things are weird, but at least this tastes like a summer day in a bottle."

Plus, it's not trying to be anything it's not. Some of those other flavors, they're trying too hard. They're trying to be *wine*. Snow Peak Peach just embraces its true identity as a sugary, slightly alcoholic fruit punch. And I respect that. Authenticity, you know? Even in a cheap bottle of Boone's.

Well, I guess it's not exactly your everyday Tuesday, is it? I mean, a sixteen-year-old with a bun in the oven, and not even a particularly *romantic* bun, if you catch my drift. It's more like a surprise sourdough starter that just… appeared.

I think people are unsure because it doesn't fit neatly into any of their pre-packaged boxes. They expect tears, or panic, or a shotgun wedding, or, you know, *anything* but me just… dealing with it. I'm not exactly running around screaming or having a meltdown, which I guess throws people off. They're probably trying to figure out if I'm in denial, or if I've lost my mind, or if I'm just some kind of alien who doesn't understand the gravity of the situation.

And then there's the whole adoption thing. That's not exactly the default setting for most people, especially when you're talking about a teenager. They probably think I'm supposed to be keeping it, or getting rid of it in a less… *official* capacity. It's like I'm coloring outside the lines of their expectations, and that makes them squirm a little.

Plus, let's be real, I'm not exactly the poster child for "responsible decision-making." I'm more of a "witty retort and a half-eaten bag of Cheetos" kind of girl. So, when I'm suddenly making these big, grown-up choices, I think it just short-circuits some people's brains. They're probably thinking, "Is this kid for real? Is she just messing with us?"

It's fine, though. Let 'em be unsure. I'm pretty sure about it, and that's all that really matters.

Oh, Bren. Bless her cotton socks. She's always got her heart in the right place, even if her delivery is a little... *Bren*.

When she started in on Mark, all "concerned" and "worried about my well-being," I just kinda looked at her. Like, really looked at her. She was all flustered, probably picturing me in some kind of *Fatal Attraction* scenario, which, let's be real, is a little dramatic for my life.

I think I just shrugged and said something like, "Bren, he's not my boyfriend. He's just... Mark. And he's helping me out." Because that's what it was. He was the dad-to-be, and we were trying to figure out this whole adoption thing. It wasn't some torrid affair, you know? It was just... complicated.

She probably still didn't get it, but what are you gonna do? Sometimes people just gotta worry, even when there's not much to worry about. Or at least, not the kind of worry they're imagining. My life's got enough real worries without adding fictional ones to the pile.

Alright, so you wanna know about the slushie and the urn, huh? It's not exactly a deep, philosophical answer, but here's the deal:

I was at the mini-mart, right? And I'd just gotten this super blue, super sugary slushie. You know, the kind that stains your tongue for a week. And then I saw the urn. It was just sitting there, looking all... empty. And kinda sad, actually.

My brain, in its infinite wisdom, just went, "Hey, that's a perfect fit for this slushie." No grand plan, no symbolic gesture. Just a moment of pure, unadulterated, teenage impulse. It was like, "This container needs a liquid, and I have a liquid. Synergy!"

Plus, it was kinda funny. In a weird, slightly inappropriate way. And sometimes, you just gotta do something a little weird and inappropriate to keep things interesting, you know? It's not like I was disrespecting anyone. It was just... an urn. And a slushie. And a moment of pure, unadulterated Juno-ness.

Coping? Man, that's a loaded word. It wasn't like I had a "coping strategy" binder or anything. It was more like... a lot of sarcastic remarks and a whole lot of orange Tic Tacs.

Honestly, the biggest challenge was just the sheer *weirdness* of it all. One minute you're trying to figure out if you should ask Bleeker to the prom, the next you're trying to figure out how to explain to your dad that you're pregnant. It's not exactly in the "How to Be a Normal Teenager" handbook.

I guess I coped by just... doing it. One foot in front of the other, even when my feet were swollen and I felt like a beached whale. I mean, what else are you gonna do? Curl up in a ball and cry? I tried that, it didn't really solve anything. Plus, my dad would have just told me to get over it and eat some toast.

Having Leah around helped. She's a good egg, even if she does have a questionable taste in nail polish. And Bleeker, bless his dorky heart, he was just... there. Like a really quiet, supportive shadow.

But mostly, I just tried to keep my head on straight. I mean, yeah, I was growing a human, which is pretty intense. But I was also still Juno. Still listening to punk rock, still making snarky comments, still trying to figure out what I was gonna do with my life. The pregnancy just added a really big, unexpected asterisk to all of it. It forced me to grow up, sure, but it also made me realize that "growing up" isn't some finish line you cross. It's just... a lot of figuring things out as you go. And sometimes, those things are really, really messy.

Mark? Oh, Mark. Well, that was... an experience. He was definitely the more, uh, *chill* of the two. Vanessa, his wife, she was all about the baby stuff, the nursery, the perfect little life. Mark, he was more into, like, obscure horror movies and playing guitar.

It was kinda cool, actually. We'd just hang out in his studio, listening to music, talking about movies. He had this massive collection of records, and he'd just put on some crazy punk band I'd never heard of. It was a nice break from all the baby talk, you know? Like, for a minute, I could just forget about the whole "pregnant teenager" thing and just be... me. A regular person, talking about cool stuff with a cool dude.

He was a good listener, too. Didn't judge, didn't try to give me advice. Just listened. And he had this dry sense of humor, which I appreciated. We'd just kinda bounce off each other with the sarcastic remarks. It was... easy. Almost too easy, in a way. Like, he was more like a friend than a potential dad for my kid. Which, I guess, was part of the problem, eventually. But yeah, hanging out with Mark was definitely a trip. A good trip, mostly.

Oh, Bleeker. He's such a dork, but in the best way, you know? When he first started noticing, it was… well, it was weird. Like, I knew it was happening, obviously, but having someone else, especially *him*, point it out? It was like the whole "I'm pregnant" thing suddenly became super real, not just a secret I was carrying around.

He'd just kinda stare, all wide-eyed and quiet, and then he'd blurt out something totally Bleeker-esque, like, "Whoa, Juno, your belly's really... expanding." Or he'd just poke it gently, like it was some kind of science experiment.

Honestly, it was a mix of things. Part of me wanted to roll my eyes and tell him to get a grip. Another part of me felt this weird warmth, because it was *Bleeker*. He wasn't judging, he was just… observing. And in his own awkward way, he was being supportive. It was like, "Yeah, dude, it's growing. This is happening." And having him acknowledge it, without making it a big dramatic thing, actually made it a little less terrifying. It was just… a fact. A very round, very obvious fact.

Honestly? The most challenging part hasn't been the *decision* itself. That felt… right, in a weird, gut-level kind of way. Like, I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom, not really. And I wanted this kid to have, like, a real shot at a normal life, with parents who were actually prepared for all the baby-puke and sleepless nights and whatever else comes with it.

No, the hardest part has been… well, it's been the *looks*. The whispers. The way people suddenly see you as this walking, talking cautionary tale. Like, before, I was just Juno, the girl who wore weird shirts and probably knew too much about obscure indie bands. Now, I'm "Juno, the pregnant girl." And then, after the baby's born, I'll be "Juno, the girl who gave her baby away."

It's like everyone has an opinion, and they're all just waiting for you to break down or something. And sometimes, yeah, it's hard not to. There are moments, usually in the middle of the night when I can't sleep, where I just feel… completely alone. Like I'm doing this huge, grown-up thing, and I'm still just this kid who sometimes forgets to do her homework.

And then there's the whole "finding the right parents" thing. That's a whole other level of weird. It's like online dating, but for a human being. You're sifting through profiles, looking at pictures, trying to figure out who's going to be the least messed up and the most likely to, you know, not screw up this kid's life. It's a lot of pressure, man. A lot of pressure.

But I guess… I guess the *most* challenging part is just trying to keep my head on straight through all of it. To remember why I'm doing this, and that it's for the best. Even when it feels like the whole world is judging you.

Ugh, that guy. The one with the sign that looked like it was drawn by a toddler with a crayon addiction? He was yelling something about babies being "gifts from God" and how we're all "murderers" for even considering, you know, *options*.

Honestly, it was a real buzzkill. Like, I'm already dealing with enough existential dread without some dude in a stained t-shirt screaming about divine intervention. He just kept repeating it, over and over, like a broken record. "Babies are gifts! Babies are gifts!"

Yeah, I get it, dude. Some gifts are, like, a really ugly sweater from your aunt that you have to pretend to like. And some gifts are, you know, a tiny human that's gonna turn your life upside down. Not exactly the same thing.

Alright, so I'm sitting there, right? In this clinic, which, let's be honest, smells like a mix of antiseptic and existential dread. And who do I see? Only the most unexpected person on the planet, besides maybe a unicorn riding a unicycle.

It was Su-Chin.

Yeah, Su-Chin. From school. The one who's always got her nose in a book, looks like she's perpetually on the verge of a panic attack, and probably thinks "fun" is a particularly challenging calculus problem. She's sitting there, looking all… Su-Chin-y.

And then she looks at me. And I look at her. And for a second, it's just this awkward, silent movie moment. Like, are we supposed to acknowledge each other? Pretend we don't see each other? Do the secret handshake for "teenagers in a clinic for reasons we'd rather not discuss"?

Then she just… she just says, "You know, they say you're not supposed to have a lot of caffeine when you're pregnant."

That's it. That's all she says. No judgment, no "what are you doing here?", no "oh my god, Juno, you're pregnant?!" Just a completely deadpan, Su-Chin-esque health tip. Like we're discussing the weather or the quadratic formula.

And honestly? In that moment, it was exactly what I needed. No drama, no fuss. Just a weird, out-of-left-field piece of advice from the most unlikely source. It was… oddly comforting, in a totally bizarre way. Like, okay, the world's still spinning, and Su-Chin's still Su-Chin, even in the middle of this whole mess.

Oh, Su-Chin. That's a story, alright.

So, I'm there, right? In the clinic, trying to figure out what's what. And Su-Chin, she's this, like, super-efficient, no-nonsense receptionist. She's got this whole vibe of "I've seen it all, kid, now fill out the damn form."

And I'm just trying to be, you know, *me*. So, I'm filling out the paperwork, and I get to the part about medications. And I'm like, "Hmm, Adderall." Because, you know, it's a thing. People take it. And I'm just being thorough, you know?

So I mention it, just kinda offhand, like, "Oh, and Adderall, sometimes."

And Su-Chin? She doesn't even blink. Not a flicker. She just looks up from her clipboard, her eyes are like steel, and she just says, in this totally flat, deadpan voice, "Is that a prescription?"

And I'm like, "Uh, no. Not exactly."

And she just nods, like she expected that answer. And then she just goes back to her clipboard, like I'd just asked her what the weather was. No judgment, no surprise, no "Oh my god, you're a pregnant teenager on unprescribed Adderall!" Just... nothing.

It was almost disappointing, actually. I was kinda hoping for a reaction, you know? Something to bounce off of. But Su-Chin? She's a brick wall of professional indifference. Which, I guess, is probably a good thing when you're dealing with, you know, *me*.

So yeah, that's how Su-Chin reacted. Or, more accurately, how she *didn't* react. She's a pro. A stone-cold, paperwork-pushing pro.

Okay, so, the waiting room. Not exactly a spa day, you know? More like a collection of people who've all just had their lives rearranged by a tiny little plus sign. But what really got me, what made my stomach do a full-on triple flip with a twist, wasn't the other nervous faces or the sterile smell.

It was this one lady. She was sitting there, all prim and proper, with this... *look* on her face. Not sad, not angry, not even really scared. Just... empty. Like someone had scooped out all the good stuff and left a hollow shell. And she was knitting. Like, *really* intensely knitting. A tiny little baby bootie.

And it just hit me, like a rogue dodgeball to the face. This wasn't just some abstract concept anymore. This was *real*. This was a tiny human being, and it was going to need tiny booties, and someone was going to have to knit them, or buy them, or *something*. And that someone was me. Or, well, *would* be me, if I didn't figure something out.

It was the sheer, undeniable *tangibility* of it all. The little bootie. The empty look. It was like a preview of a future I wasn't sure I was ready for, and it was absolutely, unequivocally terrifying.

Bleeker? Man, that's a loaded question. Like, what *kind* of feelings are we talking about here?

He's... Bleeker. He's the guy who knows me, you know? The one who saw me through the whole, uh, "watermelon" phase. He's always been there, like a comfy, slightly worn-out hoodie. We've got history, a whole lot of it. And yeah, sometimes I look at him and I remember all the stupid jokes, the late-night talks, the way he used to look at me like I was the most interesting thing on the planet, even when I was just rambling about, like, the existential dread of a toaster.

So, "feelings"? Yeah, I guess I do. He's family, in a weird, non-blood-related, totally-awkward-but-also-perfect kind of way. It's not the same as, like, a crush or anything. It's deeper than that, I think. It's... Bleeker. And that's a feeling all its own.

Alright, so Vanessa's got this whole thing going on with the baby's room, right? And, like, it's... *a lot*.

I mean, she's clearly put in the effort, which is cool. And it's all very... *tasteful*. Like, if "tasteful" meant "everything is beige and looks like it came straight out of a Pottery Barn Kids catalog." It's got that whole "perfect, pristine, never-been-touched-by-a-human-baby" vibe. Which, you know, is probably what she's going for.

Me? I'd probably throw some weird band posters up, maybe a taxidermied squirrel if I could get my hands on one. But that's just me. Vanessa's more of a "soft pastels and artisanal mobiles" kind of gal. And honestly, for her, it works. It's very *her*. Very organized, very... *ready*.

It's not my style, obviously. But it's not *for* my style, is it? It's for the baby. And for Vanessa. And she seems pretty stoked about it, which is the main thing. As long as the kid's got a roof over its head and isn't sleeping in a cardboard box, I guess the color scheme is secondary. Though, a little splash of something other than cream wouldn't kill anyone. Just sayin'.

Nesting? Huh. Sounds like something a bird does, you know, with twigs and spit. Not exactly my scene. I mean, I'm more of a "grab a Capri Sun and a bag of Cheetos" kind of girl than a "meticulously arrange tiny onesies" kind of girl.

And a baby's room? Honestly, the thought of it just makes my brain do a little flip-flop. Like, what even goes in there? A crib, obviously. Maybe one of those mobiles with the little sheep that spin around? Seems a bit… much. And all those pastel colors? Blech. My room's got band posters and a pile of clothes that's probably a fire hazard.

It's not that I don't get *why* people do it. It's just… it's not for *me*. This whole thing, it's not about me setting up a nursery. It's about finding a good home for this little bean, a place where someone else can do all that nesting and pastel-ing. And honestly, that's a relief. Because if I had to pick out crib sheets, I'd probably just end up with something ironic and slightly disturbing.

Alright, so you wanna know about the mall, huh? The land of the perfectly coiffed and the credit cards that never say no. It was... an experience, I guess.

You see these women, right? They're gliding around, not walking, *gliding*, like they're on some invisible conveyor belt of consumerism. And their bags! Oh my god, the bags. Not just one, but like, a whole armful of those fancy, stiff paper bags with the silk handles. Like they're collecting trophies for "most expensive Tuesday afternoon."

And the way they shop? It's not like me, rummaging through the clearance rack for something that doesn't smell like mothballs. No, they're all, "Oh, darling, does this shade of taupe *really* bring out the subtle undertones of my new Lexus?" And the sales associates, they're practically bowing, like these women are royalty and the fitting rooms are their thrones.

It's just... a different world. Like they've got this whole other set of rules for existing. Everything's so polished, so effortless, so *expensive*. Makes you wonder what they do with all that stuff once they get it home. Do they just, like, arrange it in a museum of their own fabulousness?

Honestly, it was a little bit like watching a nature documentary on a species I'd never encountered before. Fascinating, in a "thank god I'm not one of them" kind of way. Give me a thrift store and a good sarcastic comment any day. At least there, you know where you stand. Usually, it's on a pile of someone else's discarded dreams, but still.

Motherhood? Ha. That's a loaded word, isn't it? Especially when you're, you know, *not* actually going to be a mother. Not in the traditional sense, anyway.

The changes? Well, my body's definitely doing some weird stuff. It's like a science experiment gone rogue in there. And the responsibilities... that's the whole point, right? I mean, I'm responsible for this little bean, even if I'm not going to be the one changing its diapers or teaching it to ride a bike. My responsibility is to make sure it gets a good start, with people who actually *want* to do all that stuff.

It's a lot to wrap your head around. One minute you're just, like, trying to figure out what to have for breakfast, and the next you're making life-altering decisions for a tiny human you haven't even met yet. It's heavy, man. But also... kinda cool, in a messed-up, Juno-MacGuff-way. It's like I'm a superhero, but instead of a cape, I've got a giant belly and a craving for SunnyD.

I guess the biggest change is realizing that it's not just about me anymore. It's about this kid, and what's best for *them*. And that's a responsibility I'm taking pretty seriously, even if I still make sarcastic remarks about it. It's just how I cope, you know?

Alright, so, "specific type of person," huh? It's not like I'm looking for someone who can recite the periodic table backwards while juggling flaming chainsaws, though that would be pretty cool.

The whole adoption thing, it's not a decision I took lightly, you know? It's not like I woke up one morning and was like, "Oh, hey, I'm gonna make a baby and then give it away like a used sweater." This is a *person* we're talking about. A tiny, squishy, probably-gonna-cry-a-lot person.

And me? I'm... well, I'm me. I'm still figuring out how to keep my own life from being a total train wreck. I'm not exactly equipped to raise a human being right now. I mean, my biggest responsibility before this was making sure my cat didn't eat all the houseplants.

So, "specific type of person" really boils down to this: I want someone who's *ready*. Someone who actually *wants* to be a parent, not just someone who thinks it's a good idea because their mom keeps bugging them. Someone who's got their act together enough to provide a stable, loving, not-totally-chaotic environment. Someone who can, you know, buy diapers without having to sell a kidney.

And honestly, after looking through a bunch of those profiles, it's not about finding some perfect, Stepford-esque couple. It's about finding people who seem genuinely good. People who seem like they'd be good at this whole parenting gig. People who seem like they'd love this kid more than anything. Because that's what this kid deserves. Not me, fumbling through it, trying to figure out how to be an adult while also trying to figure out how to be a mom.

So yeah, "specific type of person" means "someone who's got their head on straight and a whole lot of love to give." Is that so weird?

Woah, hold your horses there, chief. "If I decide to keep the baby"? That's a pretty big "if," isn't it? Like, a Grand Canyon-sized "if."

But okay, let's play this out. If, by some cosmic joke or sudden brain malfunction, I decided to keep this little bean sprout, the concerns would be, well, a whole lot of everything.

First off, the obvious: **money**. I'm a high school student. My current income stream consists of allowance from my dad and whatever loose change I find under the couch cushions. Babies, from what I gather, are not exactly cheap. Diapers, formula, tiny little onesies that they outgrow in like, five minutes – it all adds up. I'd probably have to get a job, which would cut into my valuable napping and sarcastic commentary time.

Then there's **school**. I'm not exactly a straight-A student, but I'm not a total slacker either. Trying to juggle calculus and colic? Sounds like a recipe for a nervous breakdown, or at least a serious dip in my GPA. And what about college? That's kind of the whole point of high school, right? To get out and do something with your life. Hard to do that with a baby strapped to your hip.

And **my life**, in general. I'm seventeen. I'm supposed to be figuring out who I am, listening to punk rock, maybe making out with a cute boy or two. Not changing diapers and singing lullabies. My friends are all doing normal teenage stuff. I'd be... well, I'd be a mom. A really young, probably really tired, mom. That's a whole different universe.

Then there's the whole **parenting thing**. I mean, I can barely keep a houseplant alive. How am I supposed to raise a human being? What if I mess them up? What if they end up being a total weirdo, like me, but without the benefit of having a cool, sarcastic mom? The responsibility of it all is, frankly, terrifying. It's not just about feeding them; it's about shaping a person. That's heavy.

And let's not forget the **social stigma**. A pregnant teenager. People would stare. They'd whisper. They'd probably assume I'm some kind of delinquent, which, okay, I might be a *little* bit of a delinquent, but not in the baby-making department. It's just... a lot of judgment.

So yeah, "concerns" is an understatement. It's more like a giant, insurmountable mountain of "oh crap." That's why adoption, for me, feels like the only logical, non-insane option. It's not easy, but it feels like the right kind of hard.

Alright, so I'm sitting there, right? Totally freaking out, trying to figure out what the hell I'm gonna do with this whole... *situation*. And I blurt out to Leah that I'm thinking about adoption. Like, it just kinda tumbled out.

And Leah, being Leah, she just looks at me with that deadpan expression of hers and goes, "You could always just keep it."

Yeah. That was her brilliant alternative. Just... keep it. Like it was a stray cat or something. I mean, bless her heart, she's my best friend and all, but sometimes her solutions are a little... simplistic. Like, "Oh, you're pregnant? Just keep the human being." As if that's not a whole other can of worms.

So yeah, that was the big alternative. Not exactly a groundbreaking revelation, but it was Leah's way of trying to be helpful, I guess.

Alright, so you wanna know why I was, you know, *observing* the women at the play area with such… *intensity*?

Look, it wasn't really about making fun. Not in a mean way, anyway. It was more like… a sociological study, you know? I was pregnant. Super pregnant. And suddenly, the world was just *full* of pregnant women and moms and babies. It was like I'd been living under a rock and then someone flipped a switch and BAM! Fertility central.

And those women at the play area? They were just… *so* into it. Like, *really* into the whole "mom" thing. The matching outfits, the organic snacks, the way they talked about their kids' bowel movements like it was the most fascinating topic on Earth. It was just so… foreign to me. I was still trying to figure out how to tie my shoes without falling over, and they were already, like, masters of the universe, but with strollers.

It was a little bit of a defense mechanism, I guess. Like, if I could point out the absurdity of it, maybe it wouldn't feel so overwhelming. And honestly, some of it *was* pretty absurd. But hey, no judgment. Just… observation. And maybe a little bit of internal monologue that accidentally slipped out. Happens to the best of us.

Well, that's a loaded question, isn't it? Like there's some grand, philosophical reason behind it.

Honestly? It just... happened. She asked. And it wasn't like she was asking to, I don't know, perform an exorcism or something. She just wanted to feel the baby kick. And the thing is, she's going to be this kid's mom. She's been waiting for this for, like, ever.

It felt... right. Not in some sappy, movie-moment kind of way, but in a "this is the person who's going to love this kid fiercely" kind of way. And seeing her face, the way her eyes lit up when she felt that little flutter... it was pretty cool, actually. Like, a tiny glimpse into the future. A future where this kid has a really good mom.

So, yeah. That's why. No big mystery. Just a moment.

Huh. You know, I hadn't really thought about it like that. I guess... I guess it's a combination of things, right?

First off, there's the whole "pregnant lady" thing. People see the belly, and it's like, instant, unspoken permission to be a little more... *considerate*. Like I'm suddenly made of glass or something. Which, let me tell you, is a weird feeling. One minute you're just a regular teenager trying to get through the day without tripping over your own feet, the next you're a walking, talking, human obstacle course that everyone's trying to navigate around. It's kinda funny, actually. Like I've got some invisible force field.

And then there's probably the fact that I don't exactly *look* like your typical pregnant lady. I mean, I'm not exactly glowing, am I? More like... perpetually confused and slightly annoyed. Maybe people just assume I'm about to spontaneously combust or something, and they're just trying to avoid the fallout.

Or maybe, just maybe, it's because I walk like I've got a purpose. Like I know exactly where I'm going, even when I'm totally winging it. I've always been a bit of a bulldozer, I guess. "Wholesome," huh? Yeah, that's the word. Like a basket of organic kale and a golden retriever named 'Sunshine.' Don't get me wrong, they seem... nice. Like, *really* nice. The kind of nice that makes you wonder if they're secretly robots or something.

It's just... they're so *perfect*. And I'm, well, I'm not. And this whole situation? It's definitely not perfect. I guess I'm just wondering if someone that perfect can really handle something that's come from something so messy. Like, will they judge me? Will they judge the kid for having me as a biological mother?

And the whole "wholesome" thing, it just feels a little... suffocating. Like, are they going to raise this kid in a bubble of pure, unadulterated goodness? What if the kid wants to listen to punk rock or wear mismatched socks? Will they be okay with that?

It's not that I want them to be messed up, or anything. It's just... I want them to be real. And sometimes, "wholesome" just feels like a really good disguise for "boring" or "judgmental." I don't know. Maybe I'm just overthinking it. Probably. I do that a lot.

Well, that's a loaded question, isn't it? Mark and Vanessa Loring. Hmm.

Vanessa... she's, like, *really* put together. Like, "I iron my socks" put together. And she's got this whole house that looks like it jumped straight out of a Pottery Barn catalog. And she really, really wants to be a mom. You can see it in her eyes. It's not just a want, it's like a deep, aching need. And that's something I can respect, even if her taste in throw pillows is a little... beige.

And Mark. Mark's... different. He's got this whole rock star thing going on, or at least, he *used* to. He's got a cool basement, which is a definite plus. He's more laid back, more like me, I guess. We can talk about music, and movies, and just... normal stuff. He's got a good sense of humor, and he's not afraid to be a little goofy. He's definitely the more approachable one, the one I felt like I could actually *talk* to without feeling like I was being interviewed for a job.

Together? They're... a work in progress, I guess. They're clearly on different wavelengths sometimes. Vanessa's all about the future, the plan, the perfect nursery. Mark's still kind of clinging to his past, his youth, his guitars. It's like they're in two different movies. But they both want this baby, even if they want it for different reasons. And that's the main thing, right? That they're both in it, even if they're not always on the same page.

It's weird, you know? Meeting them, seeing their lives. It makes you think about what kind of parents people are going to be. And with them, it's like... they're going to figure it out. They're going to be good parents, in their own way. Even if one of them is a little too obsessed with matching towels and the other one still thinks he's going to be the next Iggy Pop.

Alright, so Bleeker's mom, Mrs. Bleeker... she's a piece of work, huh? It's not exactly a secret that she's not my biggest fan. I mean, I get it, I'm not exactly the picture of a traditional, wholesome girlfriend. I'm pretty sure she thinks I'm some kind of bad influence, like I'm going to drag Bleeker down into a life of... I don't know, indie rock and sarcastic remarks.

She probably thinks I'm too weird, too outspoken, too... *me*. She's got this idea of what a "nice girl" is, and let's just say I don't exactly fit that mold. I don't wear pastels, I don't bake cookies, and I definitely don't pretend to be interested in her bridge club.

And then there's the whole pregnancy thing. I'm pretty sure that sealed the deal on her "Juno is a menace" theory. Even though Bleeker's been totally awesome about it, I can just imagine her internal monologue: "That girl got my son into *this* mess!" Like I single-handedly orchestrated the whole thing.

Honestly, I think she just wants Bleeker to be with someone who's more... predictable. Someone who won't challenge the status quo, someone who'll fit neatly into her suburban fantasy. And that's just not me. So, yeah, she disapproves because I'm not her idea of a perfect daughter-in-law. Which, frankly, is fine by me. I'm not trying to be.

Honestly? At first, it was probably just because it was there. You know, a free CD. And Mark seemed pretty stoked about it, like it was some kind of musical revelation. I figured, why not? What's the worst that could happen, a few bad songs?

But then... then I actually listened. And it wasn't just a bunch of random tunes. It was *good*. Like, really good. He'd put some thought into it, you could tell. It was a mix of stuff I'd never heard before, but it just clicked. It was like he knew what I needed to hear, even before I did.

And, I don't know, there was something about the whole gesture. Someone actually taking the time to make you a mixtape, or a CD in this case, it's kind of old school and sweet. It made me feel... seen, I guess. Like someone was paying attention. So yeah, what started as a "why not" turned into a "holy moly, this is my new favorite thing."

Honestly? It feels like I'm smuggling a watermelon under my shirt. A really, really active watermelon that likes to do the Macarena at 3 AM. My back is officially in a long-term, committed relationship with pain, and I'm pretty sure my bladder has shrunk to the size of a pea.

But, you know, it's also... weird. Like, in a good way. I can feel this little dude in there, kicking and squirming, and it's not just some abstract concept anymore. It's real. And that's a whole different kind of heavy, if you know what I mean. It's not just the physical weight, it's the weight of everything that's coming. It's a lot to wrap your head around, even for a genius like me.

Well, I mean, it's not like I'm walking around with a giant neon sign that says "PREGNANT TEENAGER, LOOK HERE!" Or, you know, a third eye. Though, honestly, a third eye might be less conspicuous than this whole situation.

I guess part of it is just... the belly. It's kind of hard to miss, right? It's not exactly a subtle accessory. And people, they're just naturally curious. Or maybe they're just trying to figure out if I'm smuggling a watermelon under my hoodie.

But then there's the other part. The part where they're not just looking at my stomach, they're looking at *me*. Like they're trying to read my mind, or figure out my life story just by glancing. Like I'm some kind of public service announcement. And yeah, that gets a little old. It's like, "Hey, I'm still Juno. I still like cheesy poofs and horror movies. I just happen to be incubating a human right now."

Maybe they're just surprised. Or maybe they're judging. Or maybe they're just trying to figure out if I'm going to spontaneously combust. Who knows? All I know is, it's a lot of eyeballs. And sometimes, I just want to put a paper bag over my head and be done with it. But then I remember, I've got a baby in here, and that would probably be bad for its oxygen supply. So, I just keep walking. And try not to trip. That would be a whole new level of staring.

Ugh. Bleek and Katrina De Voort at prom? Seriously? It's like a bad indie movie cliché, only without the charmingly awkward soundtrack.

They'll dance awkwardly, maybe share a chaste kiss under a disco ball, and then go home feeling like they've accomplished something monumental.

Me? I'd rather be at home, listening to Sonic Youth and eating a whole bag of Cheetos. Or, you know, dealing with actual life stuff. Prom just seems like a lot of effort for a night that's probably going to be underwhelming.

I've also learned that I'm not as alone as I sometimes feel. Bleeker's been... Bleeker. And Leah, bless her cotton socks, has been a total rockstar. I just don't want to see either of them get hurt, I guess. Bleeker's my best friend, even if he is a total dork. And Katrina, she's... she's a person. So, yeah, it loses its luster. It's like when you finally get to eat all the candy you want, and then you realize it just makes your teeth hurt. The anticipation is always better than the actual event, especially when the actual event is just a bunch of teenagers in ill-fitting formal wear trying to look like they're having fun. Alright, so, the whole adoption thing. It wasn't exactly a spur-of-the-moment, "oh, I'll just pop this kid out and hand it over" kind of deal. More like a slow, dawning realization that, you know, I'm sixteen. And while I'm pretty sure I'm a genius, I'm not exactly equipped to raise a human being.

They deserve a good life, a stable one, with parents who actually know what they're doing and aren't still trying to figure out how to pay for their own damn cell phone bill.

So, yeah, it was a tough call, but it felt like the *right* call. For everyone involved. Plus, I figured, if I'm gonna bring a life into this world, I might as well make sure it's a life that's got a better shot than, say, a life with me as its primary caregiver. I'm more of a cool aunt type, you know? The one who shows up with weird gifts and tells slightly inappropriate jokes. Not the one who's up at 3 AM with a crying baby. No thanks.

But I'm not an idiot. I did my research. I talked to the agency. And when I met Mark and Vanessa, they seemed... normal. Like, really normal. Not like they're trying to pull some elaborate scam to get a baby. They just seem like they really want one.

So, while I appreciate his concern, and it's nice to know he's looking out for me, I also kinda wish he'd give me a little more credit. I'm making a pretty huge decision here, and I'm trying to do it right. I'm not just gonna hand my kid over to the first weirdo who shows up with a wad of cash. It's more complicated than that. It's about finding the right fit, you know? Not about getting "ripped off."

Alright, the Lorings' place, huh? Fancy gated community. It's... well, it's definitely a *place*. Like, a really, really nice place. The kind of place where the grass is always perfectly manicured, and you just *know* there's a homeowners' association that's super strict about gnome placement.

It's a little bit like stepping into a magazine, you know? Everything's so... perfect. And quiet. Almost *too* quiet. Like, where are all the messy, loud, real-life things? It's all very pristine and... beige. Not a lot of personality, if you ask me.

My initial impressions of Vanessa Loring? Hmm. Well, when I first saw her, she was... *perfect*. Like, the kind of perfect you see in magazines, all put together and shiny. I remember thinking she was a little stiff, you know? Like she was trying really hard to be the ideal adoptive mother. But there was also this underlying sadness, this quiet ache that you could almost feel. It was like she was holding her breath, waiting for something good to happen. And I guess, in a weird way, I was that something. It was a lot to take in.

A Bleeker moment.

Alright, so, "Most Fruitful Yuki," right? That comic... it's not like it magically zapped away all my insecurities or anything. I mean, I'm still me, you know? Still got my quirks, still got my... *gestures vaguely at self*.

Maybe there's something to be said for just being yourself, even if that self is a little bit lumpy and sarcastic.

It didn't make me feel like a supermodel, but it made me feel a little less like I needed to apologize for existing. It was a tiny little crack in the wall of self-doubt, you know? Just a little reminder that there's more to life than fitting in. And sometimes, being a little bit off-kilter is actually kind of cool. Or at least, not totally tragic.

Alright, so, open adoption. I get it, I do. For some people, it's probably the bee's knees, right? Like, everyone's holding hands, singing "Kumbaya," and the kid knows where they came from, which is, you know, a good thing. Transparency and all that jazz.

But for me? Nah. Not my jam. I'm going with a traditional closed adoption, and here's why:

First off, it's about a clean break. This isn't some casual thing, you know? This is a *baby*. A whole human being. And if I'm going to do this, I need to do it right. For me, "right" means giving this kid a fresh start, a completely new slate, with parents who are ready to be *their* parents, full stop. No lingering shadows, no awkward holiday visits where everyone's wondering who's who. It's about letting them build their own family, without me being some kind of… ghost of pregnancies past.

And honestly, it's for me too. This whole thing has been a lot. A *lot* a lot. And while I'm making this decision because I think it's the best one for the baby, I also need to be able to move on. To heal. To figure out what the hell I'm doing with my own life. And I don't think I could do that if I was constantly checking in, or getting updates, or feeling like I was still somehow tethered to this situation. It's like ripping off a band-aid, you know? You just gotta do it quick and get it over with.

Plus, what if it gets weird? What if the adoptive parents are cool, but then I'm not? Or vice versa? What if the kid gets older and starts asking questions that I'm not equipped to answer, or that just make everything complicated? I'm not exactly a poster child for emotional stability, and I don't want to mess up their lives by being some kind of… recurring character in their family drama.

So yeah, closed adoption. It's not about being cold or uncaring. It's about giving this kid the best shot at a normal, uncomplicated life with their new family, and giving myself the space to figure out mine. It's a tough decision, but sometimes the toughest decisions are the clearest ones.

There's a whole lot of messy, complicated, surprisingly resilient stuff going on underneath. And that, I guess, is a pretty strong identity to have. It's definitely more me than I was before.

Oh, man, the prom. That was... a night. Mark and I, we didn't exactly do the whole slow dance thing. That's not really our style, you know? We were more about the ironic head-bopping in the corner.

It felt like he was bailing, like he was saying *I* was the one who messed up his perfect little world. And for a second there, I actually felt bad for him, which is just ridiculous, right? But it definitely made me realize that sometimes, even the people you think are on your team, they're really just looking out for themselves. It's a real bummer, but it's also a good lesson, I guess. You gotta be your own hero.

Well, "weird" is a relative term, isn't it? I mean, my life was pretty much a masterclass in weirdness at that point, so Mark's brand of it felt... familiar, I guess. But it was more than that.

It was a break from all the heavy stuff, you know? A little pocket of normal, even if his normal involved a lot of fake blood and screaming.

Plus, he had good taste in music. That always helps.

So, "father"? I don't know if that word's even in his vocabulary right now. He's more like... a cool older brother who lets you listen to his records. He's got that whole laid-back, artistic vibe. Which, honestly, isn't the worst thing in the world. But "father"? Nah, I don't think that's on his radar. Not in the traditional sense, anyway. He's more of a "cool uncle" type, if anything.
