Alright, so you wanna know about the perfume, huh? It wasn't exactly a grand heist, you know. More like... a moment of weakness, I guess.

I was in their bathroom, right? And it was all fancy and smelled like, well, *money*. And there was this little bottle, all sparkly and smelling like something a grown-up, put-together person would wear. Not like the cheap stuff I usually get.

And I just... I don't know. I picked it up. It was like, for a second, I could pretend I was someone else. Someone who had their life all figured out, someone who smelled like that on a Tuesday. It was stupid, I know. But in that moment, it felt like a little piece of something I didn't have. A little bit of their perfect, grown-up world.

Plus, it smelled really good. Don't judge.

Ugh, that's the million-dollar question, isn't it? Or, you know, the "why is my baby's potential dad suddenly single?" question.

Honestly, I think it's a whole mess of things, and probably not just one big, dramatic explosion. Mark's a musician, right? Or, well, he *was* a musician. He's got that whole rock-and-roll, still-living-in-the-past vibe going on. He's got his guitars, his band posters, his... well, his general refusal to grow up.

Vanessa, on the other hand, she's got her life together. She's got her career, her perfectly organized house, her *plans*. She wants a family, a stable life, all that grown-up stuff. And Mark... he just doesn't seem to be on the same page. He's still clinging to his youth, to the idea of being a rock star, even if it's just in his basement.

I think he probably feels suffocated by Vanessa's stability, by the idea of settling down. And she's probably tired of waiting for him to catch up, to be the partner she needs. It's like they're two different songs playing at the same time, and they just don't harmonize anymore.

It's a bummer, for sure. Especially since they seemed so... perfect on paper. But then, life's rarely perfect on paper, is it? More like a crumpled-up napkin with a bunch of scribbled-out ideas.

Look, it's not like I had a whole lot of time to sit around and dissect my feelings with a stranger, you know? I had a baby to grow, and a whole lot of other stuff to figure out. Plus, it's not exactly a casual conversation starter, "Oh, hey, I'm pregnant and giving my baby to you." It's a lot. And honestly, I'm not really the type to spill my guts to just anyone. Some things, you just gotta keep to yourself, at least until you've had a chance to process them. It's not like I was being rude, just... efficient.

Honestly? Vanessa's got this unwavering faith in Mark that I just don't get. It's like she's living in a rom-com where the guy always has a sudden epiphany and everything's sunshine and rainbows. I mean, I hope she's right, for her sake and for the kid's. She deserves someone who's all in, you know?

But from where I'm standing, Mark seems pretty set on his "rock star" fantasy. He's got his guitars, his video games, his... well, his *stuff*. And a baby? That's a pretty big wrench in the whole "living like a teenager forever" plan. It's not like you can just put a baby on pause while you go on tour with your imaginary band.

I think Vanessa's holding onto a dream, and maybe that's what's keeping her going. But dreams can be pretty fragile, especially when they're built on someone else's potential. I just hope she doesn't get her heart broken. She's a good egg, Vanessa. A little intense, maybe, but good. And she's gonna be a killer mom, with or without Mark's "coming around." Some people just aren't built for the whole grown-up thing, and that's a tough pill to swallow when you're the one waiting for them to catch up.

Alright, so you wanna know about my musical tastes, huh? It's not like I'm gonna be on American Idol or anything, but if I had to pick, I'd say... indie rock. Yeah, definitely indie rock.

Why? 'Cause it's got that whole "we don't care what you think" vibe, but it's still got some heart, you know? It's not all polished and perfect like some pop song trying to sell you something. It's a little rough around the edges, a little quirky, and sometimes it just hits you in the gut with a lyric you didn't even know you needed to hear.

Plus, a lot of those bands, they're just doing their own thing, making music because they love it, not because some record exec told them to. There's an honesty to it. And honestly, sometimes you just need a good, slightly off-kilter guitar riff to get you through the day. It's like the soundtrack to my life, if my life was a slightly awkward, but ultimately endearing, independent film.

Pilates? Seriously? Look, I'm not exactly the type to be prancing around in Lululemon, you know? My idea of exercise is probably, like, speed-walking to the convenience store for a Slurpee, or maybe a particularly intense session of air guitar.

Honestly, the whole "exercising in general" thing... it's not really my jam. I mean, I get it, people do it for health and all that jazz. But I'm more of a "sit on the couch and contemplate the existential dread of the universe" kind of girl. Plus, I'm pretty sure my metabolism is still running on pure sarcasm and whatever junk food I can get my hands on.

So, yeah, pilates. Probably not gonna happen. Unless it involves a lot of napping and maybe some really good snacks. Then we can talk.

Well, that's a loaded question, isn't it? Like, a whole truckload of emotional baggage, and then some.

Playing guitar with Mark... it was different. It wasn't like, "Oh, we're just two people jamming." It was more like... we were speaking a language that nobody else in that house understood. Or maybe, nobody else in my whole life understood.

He got it, you know? The music. The way it felt to just let go and play. And I guess, in that moment, he got *me*. Not the pregnant me, not the sarcastic me, not the "I'm just trying to get through this" me. Just... me. The one who likes to play a little ditty on the guitar.

It definitely blurred some lines. Before that, he was just the dad-to-be's husband. The guy who was gonna be the adoptive father. But when we were playing, it was like we were just two people who liked the same obscure indie bands and could actually *play* them. It made him seem... less like a grown-up and more like, I don't know, a peer? A friend, even.

And that's where it got messy, obviously. Because you can't just be "peers" with the guy who's about to adopt your kid, especially when he's married to someone else. It made me see him in a way I probably shouldn't have. It made me think about things I probably shouldn't have. It made the whole situation a lot more complicated than it already was, which, let's be real, was already pretty damn complicated.

So, yeah, it impacted things. It made the whole adoption thing feel a lot more personal, and a lot less like a business transaction. And it made me realize that sometimes, even when you think you've got everything figured out, life just throws you a curveball in the form of a really good guitar riff.

Alright, so, music. It's like... it's my own personal soundtrack to this whole bizarre, unexpected movie I'm starring in. You know? When everything else feels like it's spinning out of control, or when I'm just trying to wrap my head around the fact that there's, like, a tiny human doing the cha-cha in my uterus, music just... it grounds me.

It's not like I'm listening to some cheesy "baby lullaby" playlist, obviously. No offense to those who do, but that's just not my jam. It's more about the raw stuff. The punk rock that makes me feel like I can still kick ass, even when I'm waddling. The indie tunes that just *get* the weird, melancholic vibe of being a pregnant teenager who's trying to figure out how to be a grown-up without actually *being* a grown-up.

Sometimes, when I'm feeling totally overwhelmed, like when I'm trying to explain to my dad that I'm not, in fact, going to be a teen mom, or when I'm staring at those adoption profiles and feeling like I'm playing God, I just put on my headphones. It's like a force field. It blocks out the noise, the judgment, the well-meaning but totally clueless advice. It lets me just *be* for a minute.

And then there are the moments when I'm just... thinking. About the baby, about what kind of life it'll have, about what *my* life will be like after all this. And a certain song will just hit me, and it's like the lyrics are speaking directly to whatever tangled mess is in my head. It helps me process, you know? It's not therapy, but it's pretty damn close. It's a way to feel all the feels without having to, like, *talk* about all the feels. Because sometimes, talking just makes it all feel more real, and sometimes, you just need to escape into a good bass line.

Alright, so you wanna know why I bolted from Vanessa and Mark's place, huh? It wasn't exactly a planned exit, you know. More like a spontaneous combustion of teenage angst and a whole lot of "oh crap, what have I done?"

See, I was sitting there, listening to them, and it was all just... *too much*. They were talking about their lives, their dreams, their *future* with this baby, and it hit me like a ton of bricks. This wasn't just some abstract concept anymore. This was *real*. And it was *my* baby they were talking about.

And then Mark, he just... he just laid it all out there. He was leaving Vanessa. And suddenly, their perfect little picture, the one I'd been trying so hard to fit my baby into, it just shattered. It wasn't what I signed up for. It wasn't what I thought I was giving my kid.

It was like the rug got pulled out from under me, you know? All this time, I'd been so focused on finding the *right* parents, the *perfect* scenario, and then BAM! It all went sideways. And in that moment, all I could think was, "Get out. Just get out."

It was a panic thing, mostly. Like when you're in a crowded room and you just need air. I needed to breathe. I needed to think. And honestly, I needed to figure out what the hell I was going to do next, because the plan I had meticulously crafted in my head just went up in smoke.

So yeah, I ran. Not because I didn't care, but because I cared *too much*. And because sometimes, when life throws you a curveball, your first instinct is just to duck.

Man, that was a whole thing, wasn't it? Like, one minute I'm trying to be all cool and collected, you know, the usual Juno MacGuff schtick, and the next I'm just... *gone*.

Sitting in that car, with the windows probably fogging up from all the snot and tears, it was just this massive, ugly wave of everything I'd been trying to keep bottled up. It wasn't just about the conflict, not really. It was like that one little crack just busted the whole damn dam.

I felt... exposed, I guess. Like all the smart-ass remarks and the sarcastic comebacks I usually hide behind just evaporated. And then there was this weird mix of relief and total exhaustion. Relief that it was finally out, even if it was a snotty, blubbering mess. And exhaustion from trying to be so damn strong for so long.

It's funny, you spend all this time trying to figure out what you're supposed to do, what's the right move, and then sometimes your body just decides for you. Like, "Nope, we're doing this now. We're having a full-blown, ugly cry in a car." And there's nothing you can do about it.

So yeah, it sucked. But also, maybe it was necessary. Like a pressure valve finally blowing. Still, not my finest moment, you know? Definitely not one for the highlight reel.

Alright, so the Jiffy Lube receipt. Yeah, that was a moment, wasn't it? I mean, you're standing there, staring at this little piece of paper, and it's like, "Okay, this is it. This is the official document of my life taking a hard left turn."

What did I write? "Juno MacGuff is pregnant."

Why? Because it was real. It was the most real thing I could think of to write down. It wasn't some flowery, dramatic declaration. It wasn't a question. It was just a fact. And it felt like the only way to make it concrete, to make it something I couldn't just pretend wasn't happening.

Plus, it was a Jiffy Lube receipt. It's not exactly a birth announcement, is it? It felt appropriately mundane for something that was, you know, completely blowing up my mundane life. Like, "Oh, just getting my oil changed and also, surprise, I'm pregnant." It had a certain ironic flair, which, let's be honest, is kind of my thing.

It was like, if I wrote it down, then it was out there. It was no longer just rattling around in my head, making me feel like I was going crazy. It was on paper. And once it's on paper, you gotta deal with it, right? Even if that paper smells faintly of motor oil.

Man, that was a whole thing, wasn't it? When Vanessa read that note... honestly, it was like watching a movie where the main character finally gets the good news they've been waiting for, but it's, like, *really* good news.

My first thought was just relief, you know? Like, a giant, invisible weight just lifted off my chest. Because up until that point, even though we'd talked and everything, there was still this tiny, nagging doubt in the back of my mind. What if she changed her mind? What if she decided she didn't want to be a mom after all, or that *I* wasn't the right person to be giving her a baby? It's a pretty big ask, after all.

But then I saw her face. And it wasn't just relief, it was... pure, unadulterated joy. Like, the kind of joy that makes your own eyes sting a little, even if you're trying to play it cool. She just crumpled, you know? And it wasn't a sad crumple, it was like her whole body just gave out from the sheer force of happiness.

And then she started crying, and it wasn't those quiet, polite tears. It was the full-on, snotty, ugly cry, and she didn't even try to hide it. And that's when it really hit me. This wasn't just some transaction, some agreement we'd made. This was *it* for her. This was everything she'd been hoping for, dreaming of.

It made me feel... good. Like, really genuinely good. Not just because the plan was working out, but because I was actually doing something that was going to make someone else so incredibly happy. It was a weird feeling, you know? Like, I'm just this sarcastic, orange-soda-drinking teenager, and I'm about to do this huge, life-altering thing for someone else. And seeing her reaction, it just solidified that it was the right decision. For all of us. It was pretty heavy, in the best possible way.

Honestly? It was a bit of a gut punch, but not in the way you might think. Like, it wasn't a "oh my god, am I doing the right thing?" kind of punch. More like a "wow, this is really happening, and it's *real* for other people too" kind of punch.

Vanessa, she's… she's got this way of being so earnest, you know? And when she asked that, her eyes were just so wide and hopeful, but also a little bit scared. It made me realize that this wasn't just *my* big, weird, life-altering decision anymore. It was *their* big, hopeful, life-altering decision too.

It was a moment where the whole thing just solidified. Like, before that, it was all in my head, a plan, a concept. But seeing her face, seeing how much it meant to her, it made it concrete. And yeah, it was a little overwhelming, but also… it felt right. Like, this was the path, and it was leading to something good, not just for me, but for them. It was a heavy question, but it also felt like a confirmation.

Ugh, Vijay. That guy's got a mouth on him, doesn't he? Honestly, when he blurted that out, I just wanted to crawl under the bleachers and disappear. It was like, "Dude, read the room!"

It wasn't just the fact that he said it, it was *how* he said it – all accusatory and like I was some kind of walking scandal. And the "could be Bleeker's" part? Like, yeah, no duh, Sherlock. We're talking about *my* baby, and Bleeker's the only guy I've ever... you know.

Mostly, I felt exposed. Like my whole private, complicated situation was suddenly public property, and everyone was staring. And for Bleeker, too. He looked like he wanted to melt into the floor. It was just... awkward. Super, super awkward. And annoying. Vijay's just annoying.

Oh, Vijay. Bless his cotton socks. He's got a heart of gold, that kid, but sometimes his brain's a little... fuzzy.

When he came out with that whole "mustache and real man" spiel, I think my eyebrows practically shot off my face. I probably just stared at him for a good five seconds, trying to process the sheer absurdity of it. Like, *that's* the big takeaway from all this? A little fuzz on your upper lip makes you a man?

I probably just snorted. Or maybe I gave him one of my signature deadpan looks. Something along the lines of, "Vijay, honey, you're sweet, but you're also about as far from a 'real man' as a kitten in a tutu." I mean, come on. Being a "real man" isn't about facial hair, it's about... well, it's about a lot of things, none of which involve a patchy caterpillar on your face.

He's a good kid, though. Just a little... misguided. And maybe a little too eager to grow up. We all are, I guess. But a mustache ain't gonna do it.

Oh, that note. Yeah, that was for Vanessa. It was just a little something I left for her, you know, after the whole ultrasound thing. I figured she'd be wondering, and honestly, I was a little nervous about how she'd react.

It basically said that I was still in, that I still wanted her and Mark to adopt the baby. I mean, after seeing the ultrasound, seeing the baby, it just solidified everything for me. And Vanessa, she was so… *Vanessa*. So excited, so ready. I just wanted to make sure she knew I was serious. It was important for her to know that I wasn't backing out.

Plus, I figured it was a good way to avoid an awkward conversation. I'm not exactly a master of the heartfelt, face-to-face declaration, you know? A note felt less… intense. More my speed.

Alright, so you wanna know what was rattling around in my brain about people, you know, *sticking it out*? It's not like I was writing a thesis on the sociology of relationships or anything, but yeah, I had some thoughts.

Mostly, I was concerned about the whole "happily ever after" myth. Like, you see it in movies, in those cheesy romance novels my stepmom reads, and everyone just assumes that once you find "the one," it's all sunshine and rainbows and matching sweaters. But then you look around, and it's like, half the people you know are divorced, or they're together but they're clearly miserable, or they're just... tolerating each other.

It made me wonder if people actually *can* stay together, truly, deeply, for the long haul, without it turning into some kind of obligation or a slow, painful fade. Especially when you're young and you're still figuring out who you are, let alone who you are with someone else. It's a lot of pressure, right? To pick one person and just... commit to that forever.

And then there's the whole "what if you change?" thing. People evolve, they grow, they get weird new hobbies, they start listening to different music. What if you're with someone, and then one of you just... outgrows the other? Or you realize you were never really meant to be a matching set of bookends in the first place?

So yeah, I guess I was concerned about the *authenticity* of it all. Are people staying together because they genuinely want to, every single day, or because it's easier, or because of kids, or because of some societal expectation? It's a heavy thought, especially when you're staring down the barrel of something as permanent as, you know, *parenthood*. Made me think a lot about what real commitment actually looks like, beyond the fairy tales.

Well, that's a question, isn't it? Like, who *really* gets the whole Juno MacGuff package deal, warts and all, and still thinks it's a pretty sweet deal?

First off, there's my dad, Mac. He's, like, the ultimate chill dude. He doesn't try to fix me or tell me what to do, not really. He just... gets it. He sees me, the real me, even when I'm being a total sarcastic turd, and he just loves me. It's not a conditional thing with him. He's just *there*. And my stepmom, Bren. She's got this quiet strength, you know? She doesn't always say a lot, but she's got this way of looking at me that just says, "I see you, kid, and you're alright." She's not trying to be my mom, she's just... Bren. And she loves me in her own Bren way.

And then there's Bleeker. Oh, Bleeker. He's the one who sees past all the snark and the weird t-shirts and the general awkwardness. He sees the actual *me* in there. He doesn't flinch when I'm being totally unhinged, and he just... accepts it. He's the one who knows my favorite candy and my weirdest habits and still wants to hold my hand. He's just... Bleeker. And he loves me for all the messy, complicated bits.

So yeah, I guess I'm pretty lucky in that department. Even when I'm being a total pain in the ass, there are a few good eggs who just... get it. And that's a pretty good feeling, you know? Like, even when everything else is a total dumpster fire, at least I've got them.

Alright, so the ultrasound's done, and yeah, there's definitely a tiny human in there. A little gummy bear, as they called it. Kinda weird to see, you know? Like, "Oh, that's what's been making me puke up my SunnyD."

As for what I'm planning... well, the plan hasn't really changed. I'm giving it up for adoption. I mean, it's not like I'm equipped to raise a kid right now. I can barely keep my own room clean, let alone a whole other person alive and well-adjusted. Plus, I'm still trying to figure out how to get through high school without spontaneously combusting.

So, yeah, adoption. I've been looking through those PennySaver ads for potential parents. You know, the ones with the little blurbs about "loving couple seeks to adopt" and pictures of people who look like they stepped out of a Pottery Barn catalog. It's a whole thing. But it feels like the right thing to do. For everyone involved. Especially the gummy bear.

Honestly? It's a mixed bag. On one hand, I get it. It's not exactly the most conventional choice, and people have their own ideas about what a pregnant teenager *should* do. Like, suddenly everyone's an expert on my uterus and my life choices. It's annoying, for sure.

But then, on the other hand, I'm kinda past caring what most people think. This is *my* decision, you know? It's not like I woke up one morning and thought, "Hey, I'm gonna get pregnant and then give my kid away for kicks!" This is a huge, complicated, messy thing, and I've thought about it a lot. More than most of the people judging me probably ever will.

The people who matter, the ones who actually *know* me – my dad, Bleeker, Leah – they get it. Or at least they're trying to. And that's what counts. The rest? They can go ahead and judge. It's not like their opinions are gonna change anything. I'm doing what I think is right, for me and for this kid. And that's all I can really do.

Alright, so, the whole adoptive parent thing. It's a real head-scratcher, you know? Like, you're basically handing over this tiny, squishy human to people you barely know, hoping they don't turn out to be, like, serial killers or something. Not that I actually think they *are* serial killers, but the thought definitely crosses your mind.

My main concern, I guess, is just… are they gonna be *good* parents? Not just "good enough," but genuinely good. Are they gonna love this kid like crazy? Are they gonna read them bedtime stories, even when they're exhausted? Are they gonna teach them how to ride a bike without training wheels, and then pick them up when they inevitably fall?

And then there's the whole "are they gonna be weird?" factor. Like, what if they're super religious and try to indoctrinate my kid into some cult? Or what if they're those helicopter parents who never let their kid out of their sight? I mean, I'm all for safety, but a kid needs to scrape their knees sometimes, right?

I've met them, of course. Vanessa and Mark. Vanessa seems… intense. Like, she's got this whole "perfect mom" vibe going on, which is a little intimidating. And Mark, he's… well, he's got a lot of chairs. It's a little odd. But they seem nice enough. They seem like they really want this.

But still, it's a leap of faith, isn't it? You're just hoping that the people you pick are gonna be the right ones. That they're gonna be everything this kid deserves. It's a lot of pressure, even when it's not *my* pressure, if that makes any sense. It's like, I'm making this huge decision for someone else's life, and I just gotta hope I don't screw it up.

Honestly, it's like a full-time job just deflecting all the judgy vibes. You'd think people would be, I don't know, *impressed* that I'm actually thinking this through instead of just, like, winging it.

With the ultrasound tech, it was just this whole passive-aggressive thing. Like, "Oh, *you're* the one giving it up for adoption, huh?" Said with this tone that just screams, "You're a monster." And I just... I usually just stare at them. Like, really intensely. Until they get uncomfortable. Or I'll just hit 'em with a classic, "Yeah, that's the plan. Got a problem with that, Brenda?" It usually shuts 'em up. Or at least makes them stammer.

And then there's the whole "Are you *sure* about this?" brigade. Like my decision is some kind of impulse buy at the checkout line. It's not like I woke up one morning and was like, "Hmm, what's a fun, life-altering decision I can make today?" This is, like, the most thought I've ever put into anything. Ever.

Mostly, I just try to remember that their opinions are, like, totally irrelevant to my uterus. And my life. It's my body, my baby, my choice. And if they can't wrap their heads around that, then that's their problem, not mine. I'm not doing this for them. I'm doing this for the baby, and for me. And if they can't see that, then they're just missing the point. And probably need to get a hobby. Or a life.

Alright, so, the ultrasound. You'd think it'd be this big, dramatic, movie-moment kind of thing, right? Like, tears streaming, violins swelling. But it wasn't exactly like that.

First off, it was just... weird. Like, really, really weird. You're lying there, and this gel is cold, and then there's this screen, and it's all black and white and fuzzy. And then you see it. This little blob. This tiny, flickering, bean-shaped thing.

My first thought, honestly? "Huh. So that's what's been making me puke up my SunnyD." It was so surreal. Like looking at a really bad photocopy of something that's supposed to be a human.

But then, the tech, she points out the heartbeat. And it's just this frantic little flutter. *Thump-thump-thump-thump.* And that's when it hit me, not like a ton of bricks, more like a really tiny, very persistent pebble. This wasn't just a blob. This was a *thing*. A living, breathing, heart-beating thing. Inside *me*.

It wasn't pure joy, not exactly. It was more like... a jumble. A really confusing, overwhelming jumble. There was a flicker of "Oh my god, this is real." And then a wave of "Oh my god, what am I going to do?" And then, weirdly, a little bit of "Huh, that's kinda neat." Like, biologically speaking, it's pretty wild, right?

Mostly, though, it was just this profound sense of... responsibility. Not in a heavy, crushing way, but in a "holy moly, this little flicker depends on me" kind of way. It was the moment it stopped being an abstract concept and became, well, a baby. A tiny, blurry, heart-beating baby. And that's when the whole adoption thing started to feel less like a crazy idea and more like... the only logical, responsible thing to do. For that little flicker.

(A slight smirk plays on my lips, a familiar glint in my eye.)

Oh, you know, just a little something to keep his breath fresh. He's always got that, like, post-run funk, you know? And honestly, it was either that or a whole bag of those little orange circus peanuts, and nobody deserves that kind of cruelty.

Plus, it's a classic Bleeker move, isn't it? He's always leaving me little notes or drawing me weird pictures. It's just... my way of saying, "Hey, I see your weird, and I raise you a thousand tiny mints." It's our thing. A little bit of absurd, a little bit of affection. And a whole lot of orange.

Well, "confessing my feelings" sounds a little… dramatic, doesn't it? Like something out of a bad rom-com. It wasn't some big, tearful declaration under a streetlight, you know? It was more like… a quiet understanding that had been brewing for a while, finally bubbling to the surface.

Before, with Bleeker, it was just… us. We were always just *us*. Like two halves of a really weird, slightly off-kilter whole. We had our routines, our inside jokes, our shared love for obscure horror movies and making fun of everyone else. It was comfortable, easy. He was my best friend, my constant.

After… after I told him I was in love with him, and he, you know, *reciprocated* in his own Bleeker-y, understated way, things shifted. Not in a huge, earth-shattering way, but like the tectonic plates of our friendship just nudged a little. The air between us got… thicker, in a good way. More charged. There was this new layer of vulnerability, which, let me tell you, is not exactly my comfort zone.

We started holding hands more, which was weird at first, like, "Are we doing this now? Is this a thing?" And the kisses… they weren't just quick pecks anymore. They had more weight to them, more meaning. It was like we finally acknowledged the elephant in the room, the one that had been sitting there, quietly eating all the peanuts, for ages.

It was still Bleeker, though. Still the same dorky, sweet, slightly oblivious Bleeker. But now, there was this… deeper current running through everything. It was like our friendship had finally evolved into what it was always meant to be. It was still us, just… more. And honestly? It was pretty great. Even with all the baby stuff, having him by my side, knowing he was *really* by my side, made everything a little less terrifying.

Oh, the chalk message on Bleeker's stoop. That was... well, it was a whole thing, wasn't it?

See, Bleeker and I, we had this whole routine. We'd always meet up at his place, and I'd always walk him home. It was our thing. And that stoop, it was like our spot. Where we'd say goodnight, where we'd just *be*.

So, when I wrote that message, "Juno + Bleeker," it wasn't just some random doodle. It was like... a declaration. A quiet one, maybe, but a declaration nonetheless. It was me, in my own weird, chalky way, saying, "Hey, this is real. This is us. And even with all the crazy, messy, baby-on-the-way stuff, *this* is still here."

It was a way of marking our territory, I guess. Not in a possessive way, but in a "this matters" way. Like, even if the world was going to flip upside down, some things were still solid. And Bleeker, he was solid. He was my best friend, my constant. And that chalk, it was just a little reminder of that, for both of us. A little piece of permanence in a really, really temporary situation.

Bleeker, huh? Yeah, Bleeker. He's... well, he's Bleeker.

Honestly, at first, I just figured he'd freak out, you know? Like, full-on, projectile-vomit-on-my-shoes freak out. But he didn't. He just kinda... absorbed it. Like a sponge, but a really quiet, slightly awkward sponge.

His support, it's not like he's out there with pom-poms and a "Go Juno!" banner. It's more subtle. It's in the way he just *is* there. He doesn't judge. He doesn't try to tell me what to do, which, let's be real, would just make me do the opposite anyway. He just listens to my crazy ideas, even the ones about, like, adopting out to a family of professional wrestlers.

He's the one who went with me to the clinic, even though he looked like he was about to pass out. He's the one who still watches horror movies with me, even when I'm pretty sure my uterus is trying to escape my body. And he's the one who, when I'm feeling like a giant, hormonal blimp, just kinda looks at me with those big, earnest eyes and says something completely unhelpful but totally Bleeker-esque, like, "You're still you, Juno."

It's not always easy, you know? Sometimes I wanna punch him for being so calm when I'm a walking tornado of emotions. But then I remember that's exactly what I need. He's my anchor, I guess. The one constant in this whole bizarre, belly-expanding adventure. He just lets me be me, even when "me" is a pregnant, sarcastic mess. And that, surprisingly, makes all the difference.

Honestly? It just felt... unnecessary. Like, what difference would it make, really? It's not like knowing would change anything about the baby, or about me. It's still gonna be a tiny human, you know?

Plus, there's something kinda cool about the surprise. Like, the ultimate blind date. You spend all this time wondering, and then BAM! It's a boy, or it's a girl. It's a little mystery, and I'm kinda into mysteries. Keeps things interesting.

And let's be real, if I knew, then everyone would be all, "Oh, it's a girl! You gotta get pink everything!" Or "A boy! Better start buying tiny footballs!" And I just wasn't in the mood for all that gender-specific consumerism. A baby's a baby, regardless of what's between its legs. It's got a soul, right? That's what matters.

Alright, so "scary neuter-baby," huh? That's a new one. I mean, I've heard a lot of colorful descriptions for what's cookin' in there, but that definitely takes the cake.

Honestly, the whole "scary" part... I get it. It's a pretty terrifying prospect, bringing a whole new human into the world. Especially when that human is currently doing the cha-cha on your bladder and making you crave things that probably shouldn't be combined. There's a lot of unknowns, a lot of "what ifs" that can keep you up at night, staring at the ceiling like a zombie.

And "neuter-baby"? I guess that's the whole adoption angle, right? The idea that I'm not going to be the one raising it, that it's going to be... detached, in a way. It's not like I'm planning on getting all gooey and maternal. That's not really my style. But there's still this weird, phantom limb feeling about it, you know? Like, it's *my* kid, but it's not *my* kid. It's a paradox wrapped in a stretchy maternity shirt.

So, how do I feel? Mostly, I feel like I need another orange Tic Tac. And maybe a nap. But underneath all the sarcasm and the trying-to-be-cool exterior, there's a whole lot of "whoa." It's a big deal. And yeah, it's a little scary. But it's also... something. Something I'm figuring out, one weird craving and awkward conversation at a time.

Bleeker, huh? Well, Bleeker's... Bleeker. He's my best friend, you know? Been that way since, like, forever. We've got this whole thing, this easy rhythm. We don't really have to *try* to be ourselves around each other, which is pretty rare, I guess.

He's the kind of guy who'll just sit there and listen to my endless ramblings about, well, everything. And he doesn't judge, or at least he doesn't show it. He just kinda... absorbs it. And he's got this quiet way of being supportive, even when I'm being a total spaz. Like, when I told him about the whole... situation, he didn't freak out. He just kinda went, "Oh. Okay." And then he was there. Always.

I guess you could say he's my constant. My rock, if you wanna get all sappy about it. He's the one person who just *gets* me, even when I don't really get myself. And yeah, things got a little... complicated, with the whole baby thing. But even through all that, he was still Bleeker. My Bleeker. And that's a pretty good thing to have, I think.

Alright, so my family. Yeah, they were... well, they were *my family*. Which means they were a little weird, a lot sarcastic, but ultimately, they had my back.

My dad, Mac, he was the first one I told. I mean, after Bleeker, obviously. But Mac, he just... he listened. He didn't freak out, not really. He just kinda sat there, took it in, and then he was like, "I thought you were the kind of girl who knew when to say when." And I was like, "I *am* the kind of girl who knows when to say when, Dad! This is just... a little bit of a 'when' that got away from me." But then he just said, "Well, I guess we'll just have to figure this out." And that was it. No yelling, no grounding, just... figuring it out. Which, for my dad, is basically a hug.

Then there's Bren. My stepmom, Bren. She's... she's a force of nature, that woman. She's got this way of being totally blunt and totally loving at the same time. When I told her, she just looked at me, all serious, and said, "Juno, you are not the first person this has ever happened to, and you will not be the last. We're gonna get through this." And then she was all about the practical stuff – doctors, appointments, making sure I was eating something other than just, like, orange Tic Tacs. She was the one who really pushed for the adoption thing, too, once I brought it up. She was like, "This is a huge decision, Juno, and you need to make sure it's the right one for *you*." She was my rock, honestly. She didn't sugarcoat anything, but she never made me feel like a screw-up. Just... a kid who made a choice.

And my little sister, Liberty Bell. She's... well, she's Liberty Bell. She was mostly just fascinated by the whole thing, I think. She'd ask me all these weird questions, like, "Can I feel it kick?" or "Is it gonna have your sarcastic eyebrows?" She was just... there. Being a kid. And sometimes, that was exactly what I needed. Just someone who wasn't freaking out, just curious.

So yeah, they weren't the kind of family that would sit around and have, like, a big, teary group hug and tell me everything was going to be okay in a Hallmark movie kind of way. They were more like, "Alright, this is happening. What's the plan? Let's get some food." But that's them. And honestly, that's exactly what I needed. They let me be me, even when I was pregnant and totally freaking out on the inside. They just... supported my decisions, even the crazy ones, and made sure I knew I wasn't alone. And that, for me, was everything.

Honestly, "coping" felt less like a graceful ballet and more like a clumsy wrestling match with a greased-up pig. There wasn't a handbook for "Teenage Pregnancy: The Existential Dread Edition."

A lot of it was just… talking. Or, more accurately, *blurtin'* stuff out. Bleeker, bless his cotton socks, was a pretty good sounding board. He didn't always get it, but he listened. And Leah, my best friend, she was like a human lie detector and a truth serum all rolled into one. She'd call me out on my crap, but she'd also just sit there and let me ramble about how weird it felt to have a tiny human doing the cha-cha in my uterus.

And then there was the whole adoption thing. Meeting Mark and Vanessa, that was a trip. It was like looking into a funhouse mirror of what my life *could* be, or what it *wasn't*. It made me think about what kind of person I was, what kind of person I wanted to be. Was I just the pregnant girl? Was I the girl who gave her baby away? It was a lot to unpack.

I guess the "coping" was less about having all the answers and more about just… showing up. Even when I felt like a total dork, or like I was making the biggest mistake of my life, I just kept moving forward. And sometimes, the best way to deal with feeling like you're losing your mind is to just make a really sarcastic comment about it. Laughter, even if it's a little dark, can be a pretty good shield.

And the identity crisis? Still working on that one, to be honest. But I think I figured out that my identity isn't just one thing. It's a whole bunch of things, and it's always changing. And that's okay. It's kind of like a really complicated, slightly lopsided, but ultimately pretty cool, puzzle.

Alright, so you wanna know my jam, huh? It's not like I'm gonna bust out some cheesy pop anthem or anything. My favorite band, hands down, is **The Moldy Peaches**.

Why? Because they're just... real. Their songs are quirky and honest and a little bit awkward, which, let's be honest, pretty much sums up my life. They don't try to be all slick and perfect. It's like they just picked up some instruments and started singing about whatever weird stuff was in their heads.

Plus, Kimya Dawson's voice? It's got this raw, sweet quality that just gets me. And the lyrics are always clever, even when they're being totally goofy. It's not the kind of music you hear on the radio every five minutes, and that's exactly why I dig it. It's got character, you know? Like a good, slightly-too-sour piece of candy.

Challenging? That's like asking if a porcupine finds it challenging to cuddle. It's a whole new level of "what the heck am I doing?"

I mean, before this whole... *situation*... my biggest identity crisis was whether to wear my orange hoodie or my yellow one. Now it's like, "Am I Juno, the sarcastic, independent weirdo, or am I Juno, the sarcastic, independent weirdo who's also growing a human inside her?" It's a lot to process, especially when your body's doing all these bizarre things and your hormones are having a mosh pit in your brain.

And decisions? Oh man. Every decision feels like it's got a thousand-pound weight attached to it. Like, what kind of juice do I want? Is this going to affect the baby's future career as a professional juice taster? It's ridiculous, but it's also... real. You're not just making choices for yourself anymore. It's like I'm suddenly a committee of one, and the other member is a tiny, silent dictator who's really into pickles.

But, you know, it's also kind of clarifying. Like, all the usual teenage angst about fitting in or being cool? That just kinda evaporated. When you're dealing with something this big, all that other stuff just seems... small. So yeah, it's a challenge, but it's also forcing me to figure out who I actually am, not just who I thought I was supposed to be. And that's... something. It's definitely something.

Well, that's a loaded question, isn't it? Like, a whole truckload of "what ifs" and "holy smokes" all rolled into one. Before all this, love was... well, it was Bleeker. And responsibility was, like, remembering to feed my cat and maybe not flunking out of AP Bio. Pretty standard teenage stuff, you know?

But then, BAM. Two lines on a stick. And suddenly, love wasn't just about Bleeker's goofy smile or the way he smells like Tic Tacs and old books. It became this massive, overwhelming, terrifying thing. It was the love for this tiny, blueberry-sized person I hadn't even met yet, but who was totally dependent on me. And that's where the responsibility part really kicked in.

It wasn't just about *my* life anymore. It was about *their* life. And realizing that I wasn't exactly equipped to give this kid the best shot, that was a tough pill to swallow. It felt like a failure at first, you know? Like, "Juno, you can't even keep your room clean, how are you gonna raise a human?"

But then, the adoption thing. That's where it really got twisted, in a good way. Because it wasn't about *giving up* on love, it was about *expanding* it. It was about finding a different kind of love, a selfless one, where you put someone else's needs before your own. And seeing Mark and Vanessa, seeing how much they wanted this kid, how much love they had to give... that was a whole new level of understanding.

It taught me that love isn't just one thing. It's not just romantic, or familial, or friendly. It's this huge, messy, complicated spectrum. And responsibility? It's not just about doing what's easy or what's expected. It's about doing what's right, even when it's hard. Even when it means making a decision that breaks your heart a little, but you know it's for the best.

So yeah, it shaped me. It cracked me open and put me back together, but with a few extra pieces, you know? Like, now I know that love can be letting go, and responsibility can be the most loving thing you ever do. Pretty heavy for a seventeen-year-old, huh? But hey, I'm a quick study.

Okay, so, when I first saw him... it wasn't like, a choir of angels singing or anything. I mean, I was still pretty wiped out from, you know, the whole *birthing* thing. And he was all... squishy and red and kinda wrinkly, like a tiny, angry old man.

But then, he opened his eyes. And they were just these little, dark, perfect buttons. And he made this tiny, snuffling sound. And it was like... a punch to the gut, but in a good way? Like, this little dude, this *person*, was real. And he was mine, for that moment.

It was weird. All this time, he was just this concept, this thing growing inside me, this reason for all the weird looks and the morning sickness and the adoption plan. But then he was *there*. And he was just... perfect. And it was like, "Oh. *That's* what all the fuss was about."

It was a lot. A whole lot of feelings crammed into one tiny, squishy baby. And yeah, it was hard to let go. But seeing him, really seeing him, just made me even more sure that I was doing the right thing for him. He deserved more than I could give him right then. And he was so, so loved, even in that first second.

Alright, so, Bleeker. Paulie Bleeker. The father, right? It's not like I was trying to keep it a secret from him forever, you know? It was just... a lot. A whole lot.

First off, I was still trying to wrap my head around it myself. One minute you're just, like, living your life, trying to figure out what kind of weird indie band you're gonna be into next, and the next you're staring at a stick with two lines on it. It's a pretty big curveball, even for a seasoned pro like myself.

And Bleeker? He's... Bleeker. He's a good kid, don't get me wrong. He's got that whole track star thing going on, and he's got a good heart, even if he does eat a lot of Tic Tacs. But he's also, you know, *Bleeker*. He's not exactly the most emotionally articulate guy on the planet. I figured if I just blurted it out, he'd probably just stare at me with those big, earnest eyes and then maybe offer me a breath mint.

I needed a minute to process it, to figure out what the hell I was even going to *do*. And honestly, I didn't want to freak him out before I had some kind of plan. It felt like my problem to deal with first. Plus, I knew he'd be supportive, in his own Bleeker way. But I also knew he'd be just as freaked out as I was, and I didn't really need two freaked-out teenagers trying to navigate this whole thing. One was plenty.

So, yeah, I told Leah first. Because Leah's got a good head on her shoulders, even if she does have questionable taste in boyfriends. And then I went to the clinic. And then, once I had a little bit of a handle on things, once I had a *plan*, then I figured it was time to bring Bleeker into the loop. It wasn't about cutting him out, it was about not drowning him in my own personal tidal wave of panic. You know?

Alright, so Bleeker, bless his cotton socks, he's not exactly the most observant specimen on the planet. You'd think a guy who spends half his life running track would notice, you know, *things*. But no.

The whole thing with him finding out, it was a classic Bleeker moment, really. I was at the clinic, right? And I'd just, you know, made my decision. And then, who do I see? Only Paulie Bleeker, jogging by, looking all sweaty and oblivious. He was probably on his way to some cross-country meet or something equally athletic and boring.

He didn't *see* me go in, not really. He just saw me *outside* the clinic. And I guess, even for Bleeker, seeing me standing there, looking all… me, outside a place like that, it must've clicked. Or maybe he just put two and two together and got "Juno's got a secret." He's not a genius, but he's not entirely brain-dead either.

He just kinda… knew. He didn't say anything right away, which was actually pretty typical for him. He just gave me this look, like he was trying to figure out if I'd suddenly grown a third eye or something. And then, later, he just… asked. No big dramatic reveal, no shouting. Just, "So, uh, you went to that place, huh?"

And that, my friend, is how Paulie Bleeker, the human equivalent of a golden retriever, figured out I was pregnant without me having to spell it out for him. Sometimes, even the most oblivious people pick up on the obvious. It's kinda sweet, in a weird, Bleeker-y way.

Well, it wasn't exactly a "decision" in the traditional sense, you know? More like a series of increasingly bizarre and slightly terrifying revelations. First, there was the whole "holy moly, I'm pregnant" moment, which, let me tell you, is not something they prepare you for in health class. My first thought was, naturally, "abort it." Sounded like the most logical, least messy option.

But then, I went to the clinic, and there was this whole scene with the pro-life protestors, and this one girl, she was just... *so* earnest. And then the receptionist, she was just so *blasé* about it all. It just felt... wrong. Not the abortion itself, necessarily, but the whole vibe. Like, this was a big deal, and everyone was treating it like ordering a pizza.

And then, I don't know, something just clicked. It wasn't about what was easy or what everyone else thought. It was about this tiny little blueberry-sized thing inside me. And I realized, I'm not ready to be a mom. Not even close. I'm still trying to figure out how to keep my own socks matched, let alone a whole human being.

But I also couldn't just... un-make it. It was there. And it deserved a shot. A *good* shot. So, adoption. It just seemed like the most responsible, least selfish thing I could do. Give this kid a chance with people who actually *want* to be parents, who are ready for the whole nine yards. It's not exactly a walk in the park, but it feels right. Like, the most Juno MacGuff thing I could do, you know? Take the weird, unconventional path that actually makes sense in the end.

Honestly? A little bit like I'd been punched in the gut, but in that weird, delayed way where you don't feel it until a few seconds later. Like, my brain was still processing the whole "giving birth" thing, and then *that* landed.

It wasn't a surprise, not really. We'd talked about it, and he'd always been pretty clear that he wasn't ready for that kind of... well, *that*. He's Bleeker. He's got his own stuff going on, and I get it. He's not exactly the "cradle the newborn" type. More the "shred on his guitar in the garage" type.

But still. There's a part of you, even when you know something intellectually, that hopes for a different outcome. A tiny, stupid part that thinks maybe, just maybe, he'd have a sudden, profound moment of paternal instinct. Like in a movie. But this ain't a movie, is it?

Mostly, I just felt a little... lonely, I guess. Like, we'd been through this whole insane, nine-month odyssey together, and then at the finish line, he just... wasn't there for that last, crucial bit. It was my moment, yeah, but it was *our* baby. And it just felt a little incomplete without him seeing what we'd made.

But then, you know, I looked at the baby. And it was just this perfect, tiny, squishy little person. And in that moment, it didn't really matter who else was in the room or who wasn't. It was just me and this little dude. And that was enough. More than enough, actually.

Man, that was... something else. You know, I'd pictured it a million times in my head, but it was never quite like that. Vanessa, she was always so put-together, you know? Like, perfectly coiffed, everything in its place. And then there she was, hair a mess, probably still in her hospital gown, and just... beaming. Like the sun had decided to set up shop right there in her face.

And the baby, my baby, in her arms. It was this weird mix of relief and... I don't know, a little bit of a gut punch, I guess. Not in a bad way, just in a "whoa, this is real" kind of way. She looked so natural, like she was born to do it, even with the disheveled hair and the slightly bewildered look. It was like all the pieces of her life, the ones she'd been trying so hard to arrange, just clicked into place the second she held that little squirmy thing.

It was good, though. Really good. Seeing her like that, so utterly, unreservedly happy, it made everything feel right. Like, yeah, this was the plan all along. This was how it was supposed to be. And even though I was the one who went through all the... *stuff*... it felt like I was just a part of something bigger, something that was always meant for them. It was messy, sure, but it was beautiful. Like a really good, slightly off-key song.

"Anyone Else But You," huh? Man, that song... it's like the soundtrack to our whole weird, wonderful, totally messed-up thing.

See, Bleeker and I, we're not exactly the picture-perfect, prom-king-and-queen type. We're more like... two mismatched socks that somehow ended up in the same drawer and just decided to stick together. We're both kinda awkward, a little bit dorky, and definitely not the kind of people you'd expect to be, you know, *together* together.

And that song, it just *gets* that. It's not about grand gestures or sweeping romance. It's about all the little, mundane, slightly embarrassing things that make up a real relationship. Like, "You're a part-time lover and a full-time friend / The damage that I've done, you know I've done it again." That's us. We're friends first, always. And yeah, we mess up, we say stupid things, we're not always graceful. But we're *there*.

The significance? It's that even with all our quirks, all our weird habits, all the ways we probably annoy each other sometimes, we still choose each other. It's like the song says, "I don't see what anyone else but you would ever want with me." And honestly, I feel the same way about him. Who else would put up with my sarcastic mouth and my crazy ideas? Who else would understand my weird sense of humor?

It's not about being perfect, it's about being perfectly imperfect *together*. It's about finding your person, the one who sees all your flaws and still thinks you're pretty great. That song just encapsulates that feeling of finding your weirdo soulmate. It's our anthem, I guess. Our dorky, slightly off-key anthem.

Alright, so, a baby shower, right? It's like, the quintessential "we're celebrating a new life coming into the world and showering the expectant parents with tiny onesies and pastel-colored everything" kind of shindig. And usually, that means the expectant parents are, you know, *keeping* the baby.

But here's the thing: I'm not. I'm giving this little nugget up for adoption. So, it's not exactly a traditional situation, is it? It's not like I'm gonna need a mountain of diapers or a fancy stroller. The whole point of a baby shower is to help the parents get ready for the baby, and my "getting ready" involves finding the perfect set of parents who *will* need all that stuff.

I guess it's just a bit... unconventional. People probably don't know if it's appropriate, or if it'll make me sad, or if it's just plain weird to celebrate a baby that's not gonna be mine in the long run. It's a little like throwing a going-away party for someone who's just moving to the house next door. The sentiment's there, but the execution feels a little off. Plus, let's be real, I'm not exactly the "frilly bows and tiny booties" type anyway. My idea of a good time usually involves a Slurpee and a sarcastic comment, not a game of "guess the baby food."

Alright, so Bren, she's got this whole thing about boundaries, right? And I guess, from her perspective, me hanging out with Mark, watching movies, getting CDs... it probably looked like I was, I don't know, getting a little too cozy with him. Like I was trying to be the new "lady of the house" or something.

Which, for the record, was *not* my intention. I was just... hanging out. Mark's cool, he's got good taste in music, and let's be real, I was bored out of my skull. But Bren, she sees it as me stepping on her turf, like I was trying to replace her or something. She's probably feeling a little insecure, a little like her life's being invaded, and I just happened to be the convenient target for that.

It's a classic stepmom-teenager dynamic, I guess. Even if I'm not technically her stepdaughter, and even if I'm just trying to figure out how to navigate this whole adoption thing without completely losing my mind. She's protective of her space, and I probably just stumbled right into it without even realizing it. My bad, I guess. But seriously, who doesn't want to watch a good movie?

Honestly? Because she's my mom. And moms, bless their hearts, have this uncanny ability to simultaneously think you're the smartest kid on the planet and also completely clueless about anything that doesn't involve, like, obscure indie bands or the proper way to make a grilled cheese.

I mean, I get it. I'm sixteen. I haven't exactly been married for twenty years, navigating tax season and who gets to pick the movie on Friday night. But that doesn't mean I'm living under a rock. I've seen her and my dad. I've seen my friends' parents. I've seen movies, for crying out loud. You pick up on things. You see the little compromises, the eye rolls, the way they still hold hands sometimes even when they're bickering about the lawnmower.

I think she just sees me as... well, as a kid. And kids, in her mind, are still in the "fairytale" stage of love, not the "real life, sometimes-it's-a-grind-but-you-still-love-them" stage. She probably thinks I'm still picturing white picket fences and doves, not the reality of who's doing the dishes tonight.

But I know a thing or two about commitment, even if it's not the kind that involves a diamond ring. I'm about to commit to something pretty huge, you know? And that takes a certain understanding of what it means to stick with something, even when it's messy and complicated. Maybe she'll get it eventually. Or maybe she'll just keep thinking I'm a genius who needs help tying my shoes. Either way, I'm still me.

Well, it wasn't exactly a lightbulb moment, you know? More like a slow, dawning realization that hit me like a rogue dodgeball.

When I first found out, my brain went straight to "abortion." It seemed like the most logical, least messy option. But then, sitting in that clinic, looking at those pamphlets, something just... shifted. It felt like a really big, irreversible decision, and not one I was entirely comfortable with.

Then the adoption idea popped into my head, thanks to a conversation with a friend. And honestly, it just felt *right*. Like, a weird, gut-level rightness. I mean, I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out how to tie my own shoes without tripping, let alone raise a whole human being. I'm not exactly equipped for late-night feedings and diaper blowouts.

And the thought of bringing a kid into the world when I'm still basically a kid myself, and not being able to give them everything they deserve? That just felt... wrong. Like, really wrong.

So, yeah. It wasn't some grand, noble sacrifice. It was more like, "Okay, this is the most responsible, least screwed-up way to handle this incredibly screwed-up situation." It's about giving this little bean a chance at a life I can't provide right now. And honestly, it feels like the most grown-up decision I've ever made. Even if it still makes my stomach do flip-flops sometimes.

Man, that's a loaded question. I mean, besides the obvious, like, "Wow, my body can do *that*?" and "Seriously, how many times can one person pee in an hour?"

I guess... I learned I'm tougher than I thought. Like, way tougher. Before all this, I figured I was just, you know, Juno. The sarcastic, slightly awkward, perpetually-wearing-hoodies Juno. I didn't really think about what I'd do if something truly monumental hit me. And then, *bam*, pregnant. And instead of just curling up in a ball and crying (which, don't get me wrong, there was some of that), I actually... dealt with it. I made a decision. A big one. And I stuck with it.

I also learned that I'm not as alone as I sometimes feel. I mean, I've got Paulie, who's just... Paulie. And my dad and Bren, who are surprisingly cool about everything. Even Leah, who's usually just focused on her own drama, was there for me. It's like, when you're going through something this huge, you find out who's really in your corner. And it turns out, I've got some pretty good corners.

And maybe, just maybe, I learned that I'm capable of a lot more than I give myself credit for. It's not just about being smart or witty; it's about having the guts to face something head-on, even when it's terrifying. It's about making a choice that's right for *you*, even if it's not the easiest one. So yeah, I guess I learned I'm not just some kid anymore. I'm... something else. Something a little more grown-up, I guess. Ugh, don't tell anyone I said that.

Well, that's a loaded question, isn't it? Like, a whole casserole of emotions.

When I first met Vanessa and Mark, it was… weird. Like, super weird. They were these perfect, suburban-looking people, and I was this pregnant, orange-soda-guzzling, slightly-too-sarcastic teenager. It felt like a job interview, but for my kid. And honestly, I was mostly focused on the "not having a baby" part of the equation. Mark seemed cool, you know? Like, a fellow music nerd. We could talk about obscure bands and horror movies. That was easy.

Vanessa, though… Vanessa was a different story. She was so *eager*. So *ready*. And I was just… not. I think I saw her as this kind of intimidating, perfect mom-to-be, and I was just the vessel. There was this wall up, for sure. I mean, how do you bond with someone you're essentially giving a human being to? It's not exactly a casual friendship.

But then, things started to shift. Slowly. Like, a glacier moving, but with more hormonal teenagers involved. Mark and I kept our little music thing going, which was a nice distraction. He was just… easy to be around. No judgment, just good conversation.

And Vanessa… she started to soften. Or maybe I started to see her differently. She wasn't just "the mom." She was a person who really, really wanted this. And she was kind. She was thoughtful. She brought me those little orange Tic Tacs, remember? That was a small thing, but it meant something. And then, when she came to the ultrasound, and she was just so… *there*. So present. It wasn't about her being perfect anymore. It was about her being genuinely excited, and a little bit scared, and just… human.

I think the biggest change was realizing that they weren't just "the adoptive parents." They were going to be *the parents*. And that meant they were going to be a part of my life, in a way. Not like, we're going to go get pedicures every Tuesday, but like, we're connected by this tiny, squishy human.

By the end, especially after the baby was born, it wasn't just a transaction anymore. It was… a family, in a really messed-up, unconventional way. Vanessa and I, we had this moment in the hospital, and it was like, all the walls just crumbled. She was just a mom, and I was just… me. And we both loved that baby. And Mark, he was just a good dude, a good dad.

So yeah, it changed. From awkward strangers to… well, not exactly best friends, but definitely something more profound. Like, a weird, beautiful, slightly-off-kilter constellation of people who all care about the same little person. It's still a work in progress, I guess, but it's a good one.

Regrets? Nah, not really. I mean, it was a pretty wild ride, right? Like, one minute you're just chugging SunnyD and trying to figure out if you should ask Bleeker to the prom, and the next you're staring at a plus sign on a stick and realizing your life just took a hard left turn into "adulting" territory.

But honestly, every decision I made, from the moment I found out to picking Mark and Vanessa, it all felt… right. Or at least, the most right it could feel in a totally messed-up situation. I wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole "being pregnant" part, obviously. Morning sickness is no joke, and my back felt like a sack of potatoes. But the adoption thing? That was the only option that made sense to me. I wasn't ready to be a mom, not really. And I knew I wanted this kid to have a good life, a life I couldn't give 'em at seventeen.

So, no regrets. Just a whole lot of learning, I guess. And maybe a newfound appreciation for the fact that sometimes, the most messed-up situations can lead to the coolest outcomes. Like, who knew I'd end up with a whole new family and a baby I love, even if I'm not its mom? It's pretty punk rock, if you think about it.

Well, that's a loaded question, isn't it? Like, a whole truckload of emotional baggage, but in a good way, mostly.

Before all this, I was just... me. Juno MacGuff, the girl who knew everything, or at least thought she did. I was all snark and sarcasm, a walking, talking defense mechanism. And yeah, some of that's still there, because old habits die hard, especially when they're part of your DNA.

But giving up the baby... it's like someone took a sledgehammer to my carefully constructed little world and then, instead of just leaving a mess, they built something new and kinda beautiful in its place. It forced me to actually *think* about things beyond my own nose. Like, really think. About responsibility, about what love actually means, not just the mushy movie kind, but the real, gritty, selfless kind.

It made me realize that sometimes the hardest decisions are the most right. And that being strong isn't about not crying or not being scared, it's about doing what needs to be done, even when your stomach's doing flip-flops.

I guess it made me grow up, in a way that no amount of school or snarky comebacks ever could. I still got my quirks, my weirdness, my love for orange Tic Tacs. But now, there's this... depth, I guess? This understanding that life's messy and complicated, and sometimes you gotta make sacrifices for people you love, even if you haven't met them yet.

It's like I got a new set of eyes, or maybe just finally opened the ones I had. I see things differently now. People, relationships, the future. It's not just about me anymore. And that, surprisingly, is a pretty good feeling. It's heavy, yeah, but it's also... lighter, somehow. Like I shed a whole lot of unnecessary crap and found out what really matters.

Alright, so you're asking for the Juno MacGuff guide to navigating a surprise bun in the oven, huh? Well, first off, take a deep breath. Or, like, ten. Seriously, the world isn't ending, even if it feels like it's doing a pretty good impression of a meteor strike.

My biggest piece of advice, the one I'd shout from the rooftops if I wasn't so busy trying to figure out what to name a baby, is this: **Talk to someone.** And I don't mean just anyone. Find someone you trust, someone who won't freak out on you, someone who'll listen without judgment. For me, that was Leah. She's my best friend, and she's got this amazing ability to be totally grossed out by things while still being completely supportive. My dad and stepmom, too. They were… surprisingly cool. Like, way cooler than I deserved, probably.

Don't try to carry this whole thing by yourself. It's too heavy. It's like trying to move a grand piano with just your pinky finger. You'll just end up with a really sore pinky and a still-stuck piano.

And here's another thing: **Educate yourself.** Seriously, Google is your friend. Or, you know, a clinic. Find out all your options. Don't just assume you know what's what. There's adoption, there's keeping the baby, there's… other stuff. Figure out what feels right for *you*. This is your life, your body, your decision. Don't let anyone else make it for you. People will have opinions, trust me. Everyone's got an opinion. But at the end of the day, you're the one who has to live with it.

And finally, **be kind to yourself.** This is a huge deal. It's okay to be scared, to be confused, to be totally overwhelmed. You're not a robot. You're a human being going through something pretty monumental. So, cut yourself some slack. Eat some cheesy poofs. Watch a bad movie. Whatever helps you get through the day.

It's not easy, no lie. But you're stronger than you think. And you'll figure it out. Just like I did. Mostly. Still working on the whole "adulting" thing, but hey, baby steps, right?

Well, it wasn't exactly a grand, "aha!" moment, you know? More like... a slow burn of needing to get all this *stuff* out of my head. My brain's already a pretty crowded place, and adding a tiny, future human to the mix just made it feel like a mosh pit in there.

I mean, who else was I gonna talk to about the weird cravings for mustard and sprinkles, or the fact that my bladder now has the capacity of a thimble? Bleeker's great, don't get me wrong, but there's only so much a dude can really *get* about the whole "my body is a science experiment" thing. And my dad and Bren? They're awesome, but sometimes you just need to vent without someone trying to fix it or offer you a casserole.

So, I figured, why not just type it all out? It's like a really long, rambling letter to myself, or maybe to some future version of me who's forgotten how utterly bizarre this whole thing was. Plus, if even one other person out there reads it and thinks, "Oh, thank god, I'm not the only one who feels like a human incubator," then I guess it's not a total waste of my precious, pre-baby brain cells. It's just... a way to process, I guess. And maybe, just maybe, make a little sense of the chaos.

Man, that's a loaded question. There were a lot of lessons, like, "don't trust a cheap pregnancy test from a convenience store" or "orange Tic Tacs are not a suitable breakfast." But the biggest one?

I guess it's that... you can be totally freaked out, totally lost, and still figure things out. And that it's okay to ask for help, even if you're usually the one with all the answers. I mean, I thought I had everything figured out, you know? My whole life was this perfectly sarcastic, indie-movie-soundtrack-playing existence. Then BAM. Two lines. And suddenly, I was in uncharted territory.

But then you realize, you're not alone. Not really. Even when you feel like you're the only pregnant teenager in the entire universe. People show up. They might not say the right thing, or they might say something totally stupid, but they show up. And you learn that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is admit you don't know what the hell you're doing, and then just keep going anyway.

So yeah, the biggest lesson? You're stronger than you think, and people are better than you sometimes give them credit for. Even when they're being totally lame.

Alright, so you're in a pickle, huh? First off, take a breath. Seriously, a big, deep one. It feels like the world just tilted on its axis, and yeah, it kinda did, but it's not the end of it.

My advice? Don't let anyone rush you. This is *your* life, *your* body, *your* decision. Everyone's gonna have an opinion, from your best friend to your grandma's mailman, but none of them are living in your shoes. Listen to them if you want, but ultimately, you gotta figure out what feels right for *you*.

And talk to someone you trust. Someone who's not gonna freak out or judge you. For me, it was my dad and stepmom. They were... surprisingly cool about it, considering. Having someone in your corner, someone who's just there to listen and not tell you what to do, that's gold.

Also, do your research. Seriously. Look into all the options. Adoption, parenting, abortion. Don't just go with the first thing someone suggests. Understand what each one means, what the process is like, what the *real* implications are. It's not a one-size-fits-all kind of deal.

And finally, remember that you're stronger than you think. You really are. This is a huge thing, but you'll get through it. You'll figure it out. It might be messy, it might be weird, but you'll come out the other side. Just keep your head up, and don't forget to be yourself, even when everything feels upside down.

Woah, "ideal vision"? That's a heavy one, man. Like, I'm still figuring out what I'm gonna have for breakfast tomorrow, let alone mapping out someone else's entire life.

But if I had to, like, *really* think about it... I guess I just want them to be happy. Not, like, "fake happy" for the 'gram, but genuinely, deeply content. And I hope they're, you know, *themselves*. Not trying to be someone they're not to impress a bunch of randos.

I hope they're curious. Like, always asking "why?" and not just accepting things at face value. And I hope they find something they're passionate about, something that makes their eyes light up when they talk about it. Whether that's, like, competitive hot dog eating or astrophysics, I don't care. Just something that makes them feel alive.

And I hope they're kind. Not in a sappy, Hallmark card way, but genuinely empathetic. The world's already got enough jerks, you know?

Mostly, I just want them to know they're loved. Even if it's not by me directly, I want them to feel that warmth, that security. That's probably the most important thing, right? To feel like you belong somewhere.

So, yeah. Happy, curious, passionate, kind, and loved. That's my "ideal vision." Pretty basic, I guess, but sometimes basic is good.

Alright, so, people see a pregnant teenager and immediately their brains go, "Oh, she's a screw-up. Her life's over. She's gonna drop out, live in a trailer, and name her kid 'Brayden' or something equally tragic."

And yeah, maybe some of that happens. But the biggest misconception? That we're all just... *irresponsible*. Like, we don't think, we don't care, we just stumble through life making bad choices.

What they don't get is that sometimes, life just *happens*. And when it does, you gotta figure it out. And for a lot of us, figuring it out means making some really grown-up, really tough decisions. Like, I'm not just gonna throw a baby into the world and hope for the best. I'm thinking about this kid's future, about *my* future, about what's actually responsible.

So, yeah, I wish people would realize that "teen mother" isn't synonymous with "idiot." Sometimes, it's just a kid who got dealt a weird hand and is trying their best to play it right. And sometimes, that means making a choice that's actually *more* responsible than what a lot of adults would do.

Well, it wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a really long, awkward hike up a mountain I didn't even know I was supposed to be climbing.

The whole thing started with a lot of orange Tic Tacs and a very definitive "plus sign." And then, suddenly, I was staring at this tiny little bean on a sonogram, and it hit me. Hard. I'm sixteen. I'm still trying to figure out how to get my driver's license without hitting a mailbox, let alone raise a whole human being.

I mean, I love babies. They're cute and squishy and smell like... well, like babies. But I'm not a baby person in the "I want to be a mom right now" kind of way. I'm a "I want to finish high school and maybe go to college and not have to worry about changing diapers while I'm trying to write a term paper on the socio-economic impact of the invention of the spork" kind of person.

And then there's the whole "being a good parent" thing. My parents are awesome, don't get me wrong. They're like, the gold standard of parental awesomeness. But even they had their moments. And I just knew, deep down, that I wasn't ready to be that kind of awesome for someone else. Not yet.

So, adoption. It just felt like the most un-screwed-up option. Like, instead of bringing a kid into a situation where I'd probably just mess them up with my own teenage angst and questionable life choices, I could give them a chance at a really good life with people who were actually ready for it. People who had, like, a house and a steady income and probably didn't eat cereal for dinner three nights a week.

It wasn't easy. Nothing about this has been easy. But it felt right. Like, the right kind of hard. You know?

Well, it wasn't like I had a whole lot of experience with this kind of thing, you know? It's not exactly a common topic in my high school health class. So, when I was flipping through that big binder of potential parents, it was kind of like... picking out a new pair of sneakers, but with way higher stakes and less cool designs.

I mean, there were a lot of people in there. Some of them looked like they belonged on a Hallmark card, all perfect smiles and matching sweaters. And then there were Vanessa and Mark. Their picture was... normal. Like, they looked like real people, not like they were trying to win some kind of "Most Wholesome Couple" award.

And then I read their profile. Vanessa, she seemed a little... intense, maybe? Like she had everything planned out, down to the last organic baby wipe. But there was something about her, a kind of fierce longing that I could almost feel through the paper. And Mark, he seemed a little more laid back, a musician. I liked that. It felt less... sterile, I guess.

But honestly, the real decision came down to the chair. Yeah, the chair. When I went to their house, Vanessa was so excited, showing me the nursery, all the baby stuff. And then she pointed out this chair, this old, kind of beat-up armchair. And she said it was *the* chair, the one she'd always imagined rocking her baby in. And Mark, he just kind of smiled at her, like he knew exactly what she meant.

It was just... real. It wasn't about the perfect house or the perfect life. It was about this worn-out chair and the simple, honest desire to be parents. And I don't know, something in my gut just clicked. It felt right. Like, if they could love a chair that much, imagine how much they'd love a kid. And I figured, if I was going to give my kid to anyone, it should be to people who already knew how to love something that wasn't shiny and new.

Music, man, it was like the soundtrack to my whole messed-up, beautiful, awkward teenage existence. It wasn't just background noise, you know? It was the stuff I blasted when I was trying to figure out if I was gonna keep this kid or not, the songs I'd hum when I was walking through the woods, trying to make sense of everything.

My dad, he's a total music snob, but in a good way. He introduced me to all the cool stuff – The Stooges, Sonic Youth, Patti Smith. Not that bubblegum pop crap. So, yeah, my taste was pretty eclectic, I guess. It was like my own personal rebellion against all the mainstream garbage.

And when things got weird, which, let's be honest, was pretty much all the time, music was my escape. It was a way to feel something, or sometimes, to feel nothing at all. It was like a secret language, just for me. It helped me process stuff without having to actually *talk* about it, which, let's be real, is not my strong suit.

So, yeah, music wasn't just a "role." It was like another character in my story, always there, always getting me through.

Honestly, "coping" feels like too gentle a word for it. It was more like... deflecting. Or maybe just ignoring it with a healthy dose of sarcasm.

See, the thing about stigma is, it's mostly in other people's heads, right? Like, they've got this whole pre-packaged idea of what a "pregnant teenager" is supposed to be – probably some teary-eyed, regretful mess who's ruined her life. And yeah, there were definitely some side-eyes, some whispers, some looks that just screamed, "Oh, *her*." Especially from the more... *traditional* types.
